name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the report by Andrey Novakov, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the right mix of funds for the regions of Europe: balancing financial instruments and grants under EU cohesion policy (2016/2302 (INI))(A8-0139 / 2017) and - the report by Ruža Tomašić, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on prospects for technical assistance under Cohesion Policy (2016/2303 (INI)) (A8-0180 / 2017).

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I would like to thank you from the outset for the support and cooperation of the EPP Coordinator in the REGI Committee, Mr van Nistelrooy, and for the support of all colleagues working in the Committee on Regional Development on this report. We would not be able to present quality work and good results without good cooperation with Commissioner Cretu, who is constantly trying to improve the results of cohesion policy. Speaking of cohesion policy, we must say that this has long been more than just one of the European Union's policies. These have long been more than just funds or just projects. Cohesion policy and the projects we fund through the European Structural Investment Funds have become part of the beliefs and values ​​we share - an example of how we can express our European solidarity. We have turned from an institution into a reflection of people's opinions and interests. That is why it is extremely important after 2020 to continue to maintain this delicate balance between the portfolio of financial instruments and the grants we provide for our regions and municipalities. Our central task must be to meet their wishes and needs, and at the same time, none of the crises facing the European Union or the challenges we face must prevent us from fulfilling these commitments. That is why it is not right to start talking from now on about the percentage of financial instruments, the percentage of grants, since it must be subordinated solely to the interests of our municipalities and regions. However, it is important to anticipate what will follow our intervention and what would be most important for the beneficiaries. Let's set priorities! My suggestion is that they be small in number, but provided with resources so that we can easily see the results. Long ago, what it counts from our work, it is not the reports, it is not the reports, it is not the accounting. These are the visible results that our citizens see. The reason they send us here, especially the people who work in the Committee on Regional Development, is to make their lives easier and the countries of the European Union richer. I believe that this is at least the role of our work in this committee. The new initiatives we are launching in the European Union are commendable. Many of them are successful and meet people's expectations, meet the challenges that lie ahead. However, we must not forget that cohesion policy and grants for developing regions are not handouts. They are part of the whole that the European Union represents, part of the effort to present the same quality of life in every part of the European Union. Otherwise, fencing with fences will not only be physical, but even more scary. It will be in our understanding, where instead of building bridges, we will build barriers. That is why I believe that it is extremely important with this report to launch a meaningful debate on how to maintain grant funding for developing regions and to present financial instruments for faster developing countries, while also being able to make sure that everything new, which we are presenting - both financial instruments and grants, to be equally accessible everywhere in the European Union, and I am sure - people will appreciate that.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: reporter. - Mr President, Honorable Envoy Crețu, cohesion policy is perhaps one of the best examples of how membership of the European Union can be positive for less developed Member States. The single market and the four fundamental freedoms sound great in theory, but if the Member States are too different in their level of economic development, one always gets the impression that someone is taking advantage of someone. From less developed members, workers go to more developed ones willing to work for less money than the domicile labor force, which lowers the price of labor and creates dissatisfaction among local people. On the other hand, less developed members are losing their working age population and thus entering even deeper into the long-term economic and demographic crisis. Reducing these disparities so that they do not encourage excessive waves of migration from poorer to richer members of the Union and create citizen dissatisfaction is very important for the future of the European Union. Cohesion policy has an important place in this process, and technical support, which we are talking about today, is a quality mechanism for creating preconditions for good use of funds and financing of quality projects in less developed members. Lack of administrative capacity in less developed member states is a major obstacle to better use of European money. As a rule, post-communist countries have a large administration in relation to the number of inhabitants, but it is insufficiently trained to quickly, efficiently and transparently withdraw funds from European funds. of which they would be permanently disabled in catching the connection with the more developed ones. That is why the correct, efficient and transparent use of technical support in the next financial period is so important! A new approach based on real decentralization, good education and, most importantly, evaluation of implemented projects will create the preconditions for the administration manages better and ensures greater absorption of money from the European level. At the time of writing, I have spoken to a number of stakeholders from different Member States, and I have noticed the same problem with a few - the use of technical support is merely satisfying the form that usually takes place at national level. We need to change that. This money should be used at lower levels and involve local and regional actors, anticipate and meet their needs, and training must be tailored to the target group of participants. Therefore, with this report, I call on the Member States to better report on the types of activities funded by technical assistance, but also on the results achieved. Time goes by, money is spent and results are lacking and this is very likely because there was no real evaluation system. That is why I think that the regular updating and public availability of the database on activities that Member States intend to take or have already taken should be considered. I hope that we will learn from the mistakes made so far and really dedicate ourselves to improving the future use of technical assistance. The purpose is not just to spend money but primarily to use it for those for whom it is intended, and we can only do so if we inform them in a timely manner about the training opportunities offered and create awareness that technical support can help greatly in the economic uplift of more passive areas.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cohesion policy is one of the European Union's greatest successes, thanks to it many regions have emerged from poverty and it has guaranteed the development of even the most peripheral regions. In recent years we have done a lot, but it is not enough or at least not enough anymore. Too long bureaucratic procedures, difficulties in combining different tools and funds and various delays are limiting the potential of this extraordinary policy. For example, it is necessary that the structural funds and the funds for strategic investments, which we are renewing in these days, work together to cover the various investment needs or radically simplify them, as we are trying to do in the budget committee, the financial regulation, with few but clear and applicable rules. The convergence of the various European regions is and must remain a top priority for the Commission and I hope that the future perspectives for cohesion policy can truly mark a new start for our legislative work.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Dear Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, good morning! I would like to begin my speech today by thanking, first of all, the REGI Committee, the Committee on Regional Development of the European Parliament, and the two rapporteurs, Mr Novakov and Mrs Tomašić, for these reports. First of all, I will talk about the report on the right balance between financial instruments and grants under European Union cohesion policy. The Commission of course welcomes this report, which is a key topic for the ongoing discussions on Omnibus, the changes proposed for your adoption in the revision of the multiannual financial framework, but also for the development of the post-2020 policy. In our view, the European Commission, an appropriate combination of grants and financial instruments is essential to make a difference on the ground, at local and regional level. I think we can all agree on some common principles that are needed to achieve this successfully. First of all, the financing mix must be made according to the type of investment, but also according to the characteristics of each sector and each region. We believe that a significant part of cohesion policy must be delivered through grants, and it could not be delivered otherwise when it comes to essential infrastructure, such as schools, hospitals, the care of children who do not have a direct profit. The financial instruments are the ones that complement this support for income-generating investments. At the same time, financial instruments should not be reserved only for rich instruments, and you know very well that we encourage all Member States and provide technical assistance for all regions, including the poorest, to adopt and duplicate their financial instruments. The Commission supports all regions in strengthening the capacity to use, as I was saying, financial instruments. The second principle is that of responsibility, of empowering stakeholders. I believe that this is essential to enable cohesion policy to have results on the ground. The managing authorities within our programs are our best and closest partners without whom we would not be able to implement our programs. They are strategically placed to identify those combinations of grants and financial instruments that are appropriate for each region. Instead, national and regional promotion banks benefit from fundamental expertise, which we must use to strengthen our ability to attract and make the best investments. Therefore, through Omnibus we propose to award contracts directly for the implementation of financial instruments and of course we in the Commission would assess whether these regulations proposed by Omnibus will be adopted by you and then by the Council as soon as possible. The third principle: we need a well-defined framework that allows for the development of secure, long-term projects, and so it is important that the changes we are discussing now are balanced and calibrated. With regard to Ms Tomašić's own-initiative report on the future perspective of technical assistance in cohesion policy, the Commission of course welcomes this report. Several Commission initiatives are recognized, such as TAIEX REGIO PEER 2 PEER. Unfortunately, in my weekly visits to many Member States, I often feel that not even the ministers are aware of all these tools that the Commission makes available, and this saddens me because, in fact, I have invented all these tools precisely to support the Member States. We have 250,000 field workers in the field of European funds. They have accumulated a experience, greater or lesser; some have been working in this field for forty-two years, since the Regional Development Fund was invented, others have been working for ten years, as in Romania or Bulgaria, others for four years. I strongly believe in this exchange of good practice which supports the exchange between fund managers and experts in order to increase administrative capacity between Member States, regions and municipalities. We offer these services at the request of the Member States and I can assure you that we have very few requests in this regard; so if a Member State tells us tomorrow that it needs technical assistance with public procurement, within five days the Commission will mobilize and send the best experts from the regions performing in this field. So, from this point of view, I encourage you all to make known all the tools that the Commission makes available to the Member States, free of charge. That is why I congratulate you on this report for providing valuable suggestions on the more efficient use of technical assistance, a very useful tool, especially in the context of post-2020 discussions. Therefore, I would like to emphasize once again that we in the European Commission encourage Member States to take an approach to the use of targeted financial instruments in the light of the difficulties and experiences they have faced in the past. For example, we suggested that Member States use technical assistance to complete the fulfillment of preconditions - what we call ex-ante conditionalities for investment, but also for the implementation of anti-fraud and anti-corruption actions. Unfortunately, Member States generally want to use this technical assistance in general to cover staff costs and wages. I appreciate your speech and that of Mr Novakov, who highlighted very well the challenges of labor migration, brain drain, brain drain, demographic challenges in less developed regions. We are here to help. You are right: training and preparation are sometimes more important than money, and I am glad that both rapporteurs, including the representative of the Committee on Budgets, have emphasized the responsibility of the Member States, because when it comes to implementation, one hundred percent is the responsibility of those states. We called on the Member States to ensure that all funds can support staff and authorities performing the most important tasks, including intermediate bodies, but also regional and local authorities. I believe, just like you, that we can improve the way we use technical assistance, I believe that evolution must be supported, we are at the beginning of the debate for the future of cohesion policy. We are thinking, for example, of advancing technical assistance at the beginning of the funding period, not every year, so that the implementation system can be prepared before the start of programs and the selection of projects - is one of the ideas. We could also use technical assistance to support national and regional administrations to strengthen their project pool. This will help us to ensure that the implementation of projects can start as soon as funding is available because it is very important for us to learn from the lessons of the past and not start the financial cycle with all these delays that we are now experiencing. I also registered 7 years ago. In any case, we also consider ideas such as better targeting of technical assistance to beneficiaries or exchanges of experience between regions. Thank you very much. Also from the budget, Mr Viotti emphasized the key role of strategic funds and structural investment funds, how they can be combined to maximize impact on the ground. I look forward to your comments and your suggestions.Thank you very much!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Mr President, in this period of convergence, from the year 2000 onwards, the European Union began to diverge with the less developed regions and with those less developed regions moving away from the European average and the wealthier regions. In fact, the Multiannual Financial Framework reflects this reality with a significant decrease in funds directed towards cohesion, compared to previous tables. And the question of financial instruments represents, in fact, another side of this deliberate option to subordinate redistributive and agricultural policies. I must say that, according to the hearings we held in the framework of the AGRI Committee, it has been widely proven that financial instruments cannot under any circumstances replace existing support, namely at the level of the second pillar of the CAP and, therefore, cohesion it cannot be a watchword. It implies means, but it also implies, and I cannot fail to mention it, the end of austerity policies, the end of the impositions of the single currency, which constrain national states in carrying out their public investment plans and limit, in many cases, the use of structural funds.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Commissioner, targeted technical assistance is a catalyst for the future of cohesion. That is why, Commissioner Crețu, I fully support your idea of ​​front-end funding for cohesion programs, combined with specialist technical assistance. In the new reality it is necessary for the technical assistance to be accessible and to be able to offer special services, at project level, or even beneficiary. In every region, in every municipality, in every university, in every ministry there are separate needs. There are separate people, separate resources and technical assistance can help make projects of particular importance to local communities a reality. It is therefore necessary, first of all, to increase the transparency of the expenditure of resources on technical assistance and to immediately proceed with a study on the contribution of technical assistance to the implementation of cohesion policy in order to arrive at targeted indicators and methods. evaluation for the next programming period. Besides, we have a writing sample for specialized technical assistance and this is what happened in Greece with the task force. According to the Court of Auditors' report, we have positive results in the absorption of resources, but mixed results in the implementation of sustainable structural reforms. For this reason, technical assistance needs to focus on both the absorption and the implementation of structural reforms that are necessary for the sustainable development of the Member States.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, financial instruments are a means to achieve the objectives of cohesion policy and not an end in themselves. They should be used as an additional tool for sectors where they prove to be more suitable than grants. Grants must be maintained as the main instrument of cohesion policy, especially for small beneficiaries. For us socialists, it is clear that we will focus on the projects that matter most to the citizens of the European Union. Investments should focus on areas likely to have multiplier effects on jobs and growth, such as investments in innovation, education and sustainable energy. People are the real driving force behind innovation and the establishment of just and progressive societies. For this reason, financial instruments should also contribute to strengthening the social pillar of cohesion policy. It is also important to improve the performance of financial instruments in less developed regions, that is, in regions with higher unemployment rates, trying to find measures, through positive discrimination, which help to reduce asymmetries. Finally, we want a cohesion policy that continues to distribute public funds in the European Union but, at the same time, advocates demanding accountability and accountability. It is crucial that clear rules are established and technical assistance guidelines are provided to the administrations involved to overcome the problems, something that the Commissioner has always advocated alongside the European Parliament from the outset. Finally, a greeting to all those who defend cohesion policy as one of the best expressions of solidarity between the regions of the European Union.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good work, this is a good report. Cohesion policy and the EU budget in general should have a financing system that makes it possible to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the budget, but which also attracts private investors so that the financing gap is filled as a result. I would like to emphasize that lending should not be a complete substitute for grants, but should aim for the right mix that makes the best use of businesses, regions and local government. When we look at both more developed and less developed Member States in the EU and their investment needs, we find that the funding gap varies across sectors and priorities. However, one thing is clear: in addition to the grant, other funding channels are needed. The solution can be found in the loan. The European Investment Bank must play a more central role in this. The European Investment Bank was set up in the context of the Treaty of Rome, but now is the time for it to play a more central role in cohesion policy as well. It already provides loans, loan guarantees and capital, which, together with grants and subsidies, form a functioning system of private and public funding. Problems with funding are also the lack of adequate information about the company. Training and guidance are needed at all levels of government so that a suitable range of funding can be found for each situation. The role of the European Investment Bank in disseminating information must also be strengthened. The appropriate choice of funding for each situation is an important factor in creating a new, forward-looking cohesion policy.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! There is at least one scenario in the White Paper on the Future of the EU in which EU cohesion policy would go overboard. It is about nothing less than solidarity, social equilibrium and - if you will - the freedom to invest sensibly in the regions. Who seriously wants to dispose of all these core values ​​that have practically been abolished in cohesion policy? After all, the new reflection paper “Shaping globalization” does not want this. I can only support you, Commissioner, if you keep saying aloud: Cohesion policy is not a financial instrument, but a policy with a long-term objective, namely the creation of equal living conditions in the Union. And that is why, in my opinion, it makes no sense for us to reduce the mix of instruments in cohesion policy to credit instruments. Cohesion - I want to make this clear - must not become EFSI's little sister. Let’s finally stop discussing structural fund support and grants! Let's make the funding policy more efficient in practice, let's enable municipalities and project sponsors to co-finance and ultimately achieve sustainable success! This of course includes the funding policy, especially for cross-border educational, cultural, research and scientific projects.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the growing trend towards the increasing use of financial instruments in cohesion policy since the last Commission term is a matter of legitimate concern. Cohesion policy is designed to help lagging regions. It is clear that in market conditions, more competitive players raise a larger share of funds. In the case of regional policy, these are the richer regions. Therefore, by allowing the widespread use of financial instruments, it is clear that we will not only do this for the poor, but also for the richer. Personally, I really don’t want that. Therefore, as the shadow rapporteur for the Greens, I call for a vote in favor of this report. In it, I would like to thank the rapporteur, he was able to properly assess the threats posed by the use of financial instruments. And it is not just about increasing regional disparities. This includes opacity, strengthening the partnership principle and much more. Also, the report has managed to strike the right balance between cohesion policy and the philosophy of cohesion, while not ruling out the possibility of exploiting the potential of financial instruments where appropriate. Colleagues, Ruža Tomašić's report is devoted to an important and sometimes ignored topic. The European Union spends tens of billions of taxpayers on cohesion policy. The European Union has developed rules for the use of this aid. Accordingly, the European Union must ensure that the Member States have sufficient capacity to use this aid properly. Until now, technical assistance has been funded from the cohesion budget. Unfortunately, in more cases, this support remained at the national level and rarely reached the regions, let alone the municipal level. And where else, below the municipal level, are the communities. Let us not forget that community-led local development is becoming an increasingly important instrument of Cohesion Policy. Thanks for your attention.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are voting on two reports. In the first we talk about the balance between financial instruments and subsidies in cohesion policy, but the answer we are trying to give is dangerous. A time bomb, made by the increasingly pushed recourse to opaque and high-risk financial instruments, with high costs and difficult to judge or justify, or rather, they certainly are for a crowd of banks and financial intermediaries who, through subtle tricks of financial engineering, promise the multiplication of investments, but much less for European businesses and citizens. We are at the usual promises while, in the meantime, the market is filled with products that can fuel a speculative bubble, with toxic effects precisely for micro and small and medium-sized enterprises. We risk facing a colossus with feet of clay that, on the one hand, bewitches the world of finance, member countries and the real economy but, on the other hand, can collapse ruinously, dragging companies and the lives of millions with it. of European citizens. On the other hand, the second report. The issue of technical assistance and administrative capacity are fundamental for the success of cohesion policy. However, it is necessary to avoid reproducing the errors and waste that have characterized it in various Member States and therefore, if on the one hand it is necessary to insist above all on the involvement of regional and local authorities, both in the design and in the implementation of technical assistance measures, on the other hand, it is necessary to make the related expenditure more transparent, which amounts to 13.4 billion. One thing is certain, technical assistance initiatives must allow institutions to strengthen their capacities in terms of human resources, but above all increase the transparency of tenders, quality of projects, save costs and improve competition, thanks to public procurement. best.This is why our vote will be positive.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President! The aim of cohesion policy is to strengthen the economic and social cohesion of the community and to catch up with the less developed regions. In 2004, ten countries, mainly Central and Eastern European countries, joined the European Union. If we were to ask their population now how they feel whether this catching-up has taken place to the extent expected, their answer is no. Of course, it is possible to measure regional catching-up in terms of GDP, competitiveness, infrastructure, where there has been development. But for them, the fundamental question is how their quality of life has changed in 13 years. Prices have approached Western Europeans, and the wage gap has widened. This needs to be addressed at EU level, at decision-making level. If the governments of the regions do not do this, the population will have an opportunity, the European Citizens' Initiative. Thus, the Jobbik for Hungary Movement took the lead in such an initiative, found partners in six other EU countries, and launched a wage catch-up initiative, which should be said to be a goal for developed countries as well. the consequence is that people are migrating from these countries and causing tension there. The Commission gave the green light to this initiative two days ago. He acknowledged that there was work to be done at EU level, so we expect that, once the one million signatures have been collected, the European Commission will actually take concrete steps to do so.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, I think that with these two reports we are looking for the right balance, a balance between what banks can do - loans, guarantees, banking business - and what you want to do in cohesion - socio-economic , territorial cohesion, cohesion in regions in Europe and in the whole of Europe. And then it cannot be the case that you only work with loans, things that you have to pay back. Throughout the social domain there are countless projects that you simply have to get off the ground. There is no market mechanism behind that that will pull that for a while. We get that clarity today, because now and then I read in the communication from the Commission or the EIB: "banking business solves everything". No, it really won't. So, this is a good balance here. Second remark: it is extremely difficult to work with all kinds of Revolving Funds instead of with subsidy instruments with Public Private, and we need that technical assistance for that. I also think that the Commission should also set those quality requirements with Member States that want to use new instruments and make much tighter agreements for seven years. That is a nice stepping stone to the new period. Finally, a number of things are going well. Let the stars shine. Let's see where it can be done. And let us not, as it were, talk each other down with bad examples, reports from the Court of Auditors. Let the stars shine. And I can tell you: there is an initiative of nine MEPs who are taking action. You have published an action program on communication to be tackled by Member States, regions and cities together. Let's do that action together.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we have done a good job with the two reports, which are indeed an important contribution to the season we are opening of cohesion policy review, up to the forum next June. On the report on grants, I would like to say that we point out the risks of overuse of financial instruments, but we also make a choice and give a direction as Parliament, that is to continue to keep the topic of grants, the instrument of grants as an instrument strategy of cohesion policy. It is therefore on this choice that we must focus attention, effort and dialogue with the Commission and the Council. The second report on technical assistance seems to me to be even more important. Here I point out three issues: we have made a choice of merit, not only in the sense that the instrument is important in helping States, regions and local autonomies to do more and better in programming EU funds, and the Commissioner does well to raise the issue of more information, but we have made a choice, I believe, that goes in the right direction. We have said that assistance is technical not only in terms of resource absorption but it means more quality, to understand exactly how community resources modify the fundamental characteristics of the economy and society where they intervene. More cooperation, inspired by the cohesion policy, between the structural reforms we introduce in individual countries to make them more competitive and the relaunch of a public investment policy and, therefore, an important heart of the technical assistance policy. Finally, a point on which I believe we must work more and ask the Commission for a contribution on this: not to make technical assistance an instrument outside the reform of the state and public institutions. Building a modern European ruling class that knows how to use Community resources better and able to offer new innovation and development policies.This is the challenge of the new technical assistance, not a market tool, but an ability to build a new statehood especially in many regions where we need the contribution of a new ruling class, able to make better use of these tools.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Our Parliament will vote today on the report on the Cohesion Fund. It is large, amounting to EUR 75 billion in the period 2014–2020. In this report, in point 6, we underline that appropriations for the Cohesion Fund should not be cut. In general, I think this is the right approach, as it is in harmony with the declared European solidarity. However, as we also note in the report, there are some drawbacks to financial instruments (point 11.). We note already in point 1 of the report that they were designed before the financial and economic crisis and were not the most appropriate. There are examples of misuse of these funds, but it should be noted that they go to the Member States that joined the Community later, and - despite the sometimes problematic use of them - are often the only reason for support for the European Union. Similar tendencies can be observed in my constituency, in the Lublin region of Poland, where there are high social expectations that the European Union will consistently and seriously strive to equalize the level of development of the regions throughout the Community. Therefore, when there is a budget surplus, I hope that it will be redirected to less prosperous regions, such as, for example, the Lublin region.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: - Mr President, both of the reports we are considering today, which we will be voting on a little later, focus on key areas that can improve the effectiveness of cohesion policy in the current period up to 2020, and its effective use, and after 2020 as a key tool for improving cohesion and erasing disparities in the development of the European Union's regions. Both reports address key issues such as flexibility, complementarity, the combination of the European Structural and Investment Funds with other European Union financial instruments, and also address one key issue that has already been mentioned - the good balance: the balance between the experience we already have so far in the implementation of cohesion policy and balance for future implementation. It is extremely important to pay attention to the problem of financial instruments, because this is the basis of a good balance in the future. Financial instruments make it possible to attract additional investment outside the European Union's public investment. Financial instruments allow for a more effective deployment of cohesion policy and in this sense the complementarity between technical assistance, development of financial instruments and improvement of cohesion policy is the direction in which I will move in the future. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)) (Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member!There is a controversial thing about who to focus technical assistance on.It is basically the playing field for governments.But do you agree, for example, that regional, local bodies and local governments should also be able to benefit from technical assistance?And I ask this because I think it would be necessary to implement the “smart village” concept, for example.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card. -  Thank you for the question. Of course, I fully agree that technical assistance should be addressed not only to the central managing authorities of operational programs, but also to all beneficiaries of operational programs and, above all, to local authorities. Capacity building in local authorities is essential for the effective use of projects, for the preparation and implementation of projects that are addressed to local communities. But in addition, technical assistance must be aimed at improving the visibility of cohesion policy in order to bring it closer to citizens.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: - Mr President, Mrs Crețu, the European Parliament in its two reports calls for a stronger cohesion policy. I know very well that you want it, but also within the Commission there are many who do not help you so much. We call on the Commission to do more for social cohesion and regional cohesion, because it is simply that inequalities, both social and regional, have increased in recent years. And it is not just a matter of European South or Eastern Europe. It also concerns poor regions in the most powerful Member States, and in Germany, and in France, and the millions of unemployed, and the millions of the poor, and especially the young people. So we need more technical assistance, and front-end funding, and a reduction in bureaucracy, but also more funds for social cohesion. Because in recent years even the term "cohesion" has become less and less in the texts of the Commission and, even more, of the Council. I know very well from the experience of my country, Greece, that we use these funds more and more productively with your assistance. But you have a strong ally, the European Parliament, to push for the Commission to do more. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a "blue card" (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I would ask, I agree with you that technical assistance is important precisely for drawing on cohesion funds.Do you realize that regional disparities would be far greater if cohesion policy did not exist?Ie.the differences you spoke of would be far more pronounced between regions and even within some states.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: answer to a question with a "blue card". - Mr Polčák, that is exactly what I pointed out. In recent years, differences and inequalities, both regional and social, have increased, not only between countries but also within countries, and that is why, if we want a united, prosperous Europe, where everyone can benefit from its development, cohesion policy needs to be strengthened. Not just to continue after 2020, but with more funds and more technical assistance. To place this money where it really is needed.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: – Mr President, the European Union’s cohesion policy is a crucial tool in order to bridge the inequalities between the EU’s various regions. We have to make sure that the entire Union is able to benefit from the economic development, and a transition to a sustainable society and social equality, which the cohesion policy helps promote. However, a key aspect that we believe is lacking is synergies between the Cohesion Fund and the non-cohesion funds, such as the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, which is a programme that helps promote excellent research projects all over Europe, even though there have been some challenges for some parts of the Union to fully participate in this programme.  One goal of the cohesion policy is to work as a tool in order to foster excellence so that the regional fund can become the region’s stairway to excellence and better participation in the research programme, which would benefit the whole of Europe. This is something that the Commission is trying to promote with a tool for smart specialisation strategies. This is a good start and I call on all stakeholders involved to improve the synergies in the next programme periods so that all this nice talk on synergies can actually become a reality.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Mr President, this report calls for the Commission to ‘raise the profile of ESI Funds’ investments and to make it clearer that EU funding is involved’. Let me make it crystal clear right from the start of this speech that there is no such thing as EU funding. This money comes from the pockets of citizens of your constituent nations and for you to even consider throwing more of it away on self—promotion is simply a sign that you understand nothing of the issues confronting your voters. We have already seen the decades of audits proving that the EU is utterly unable to prevent misappropriation, misspending and fraud. Giving you tens of billions of euros for self—aggrandisement between 2014 and 2020 seems tantamount to financial suicide. This budget is no more than a very expensive carnival parade, replete with all the clowns and sideshows, parading throughout Europe to the music of the danse macabre and the smell of burning money. The profusion of EU spending plaques across Europe, following this deluge of taxpayers’ money on projects which could have been done – if indeed they should be done – by the nation states much more cheaply and more effectively, may indeed prove to be no more than gravestones for your expansionist empire.  The concern this report states regarding the backlog of unpaid invoices is extremely valid. Who is going to bail out your vanity schemes when the UK leaves? Many of the nations in the south and east of Europe are already groaning under the weight of supporting the euro and your backing of the banking establishments. This empire—building will come to a shuddering halt sooner or later and, for the good of your peoples, I urge you to make it sooner.  (The speaker declined a blue-card question from Franc Bogovič)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, it has been shown that the combination of technical assistance and Structural Funds funding has not yielded the desired results, and there are shadows of scandals and cases of mismanagement of funds. The Union and the Member States are bound by specific rules. The audit of the proper use of the funds shall be carried out by the Commission on a case-by-case basis afterwards, in accordance with the provisions of the Treaties, which provide for the existence of mutual trust. Responsibility is shared between the European institutions, mainly the Commission and the governments of the Member States. In this way, institutional and administrative weaknesses, corruption, deception of Community services and squandering of European resources lead to economic deficits and regional disparities. Governments have systematically succumbed to the lures of the client state, the interests of the construction cartel, the petty interests of local actors, and opportunistic political aspirations. The effectiveness of the public administration and the private sector in making adequate use of Community funds and maximizing the benefits is obvious, in order to stop the Community budget from bleeding. Individualized solutions are needed, respect for the macro-regional priorities of the Member States and for the particularities, characteristics and differences of the individual regions. They need accessibility, transparency and meritocracy. Above all, however, nationalist-centric pro-people governments are needed.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, again today the European Parliament is hosting a momentous debate with which to try to do more Europe, with solutions to improve the very important cohesion policy, to also achieve the results that citizens are asking for. Because cohesion policy is the highest expression of European solidarity; it is that invisible tool that achieves visible benefits. The cohesion policy is the rehabilitation of the center of Malaga, it is the outer port of Ferrol, it is the Zeneta-San Javier highway, to name a few examples. Furthermore and fundamentally, cohesion policy is the one that works so that no one is left behind. It demonstrated this by creating more than half a million jobs during the crisis and helping to mitigate its effects in the most vulnerable regions. That is why I defend that cohesion policy is inalienable and irreplaceable. What must be guaranteed is that each program does its part and that there are no duplications. Not a single euro should be lost to the bureaucracy. It is not a question, then, of looking for substitutes for cohesion; because European defense is important, because negotiating Brexit well is very important, but it is more important to ensure that public hospitals continue to function, that water continues to arrive and that children continue to have good schools; because it is our duty to combat inequality and guarantee equal opportunities for all citizens, whether they live in Paris, the Canary Islands or Berlin; and we can only do that with more cohesion.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, the economic scissors in the European Union on the East-West axis remain wide open, even after more than 10 years of membership for the so-called 'new' Member States. I would like to remind you that in the European Union there are still settlements, including in my country Bulgaria, without basic settlement infrastructure, such as sewerage and access to drinking water. To date, the use of financial instruments, such as loans, guarantees and microcredits by agricultural operators, is limited. This means that these instruments are not adapted to the different economic sectors. The common agricultural policy guarantees income and supports the implementation of certain European policies. However, cohesion policy and financial instruments are helping regions grow. There are activities and projects, such as irrigation, short circuits, closed production cycles and the construction of digital infrastructure, that require economic capital beyond the reach of local administrations. Investments in such projects provide solutions to problems in regions with a lower standard of living. That is why I believe that rural areas and their operators must have guaranteed access to the available financial instruments within the framework of the European Union's cohesion policy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, at a time when Mr Draghi is spending € 2.3 trillion over two years, the European Union has decided to spend only € 454 billion between 2014 and 2020, and there is a need for increased Union intervention with resources in order to strengthen cohesion and reduce unemployment. It is also pointed out that in Greece, the largest projects financed by the NSRF, finally through the privatization-concession process, end up in state or private companies in other Member States of the Union. Thus, in the context of the concession of the fourteen regional airports, the German state company Fraport received a dowry of 520 million euros in the form of NSRF projects, which were executed and are still being executed at the airports of Thessaloniki and Chania, although this is prohibited by European Union regulations. In addition, the highways were ceded to Spanish companies, the Rio-Antirio bridge to a French company, while the "Eleftherios Venizelos" airport was managed, until recently, by Hochtief. So the 'European Union is drinking, the European Union is drinking'.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr President, I want to support both reports because they speak very clearly about the importance of cohesion policy, which is an expression of solidarity within the European Union, but also more: a chance to develop all those areas that need money from those who have more, and of course I want emphasize the importance in these reports which finally speak of the role of local and regional self-government. I have had the opportunity to implement hundreds of European programs and I am aware and know very well how important it is that local and regional governments have a decisive role in the implementation of these programs. And so, the financial mix we are talking about here in financing various projects is certainly something that is extremely important, but who will decide whether technical assistance, grants plus funds from the European Investment Bank or the EFSI fund or, God forbid, from private sector will be involved in the implementation of a project. It is a very complicated process, but I think we need to be brave and we need to continue on that path.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Mr President, I believe that we are diverting the focus a lot with debates on whether it is better to apply subsidies or financial instruments and in what percentages one or the other have the greatest effect, or what is the level of technical assistance that is needed; debate that is necessary, without a doubt, but first we should focus on another priority. We continue to have a Europe that is harshly divided between first-class regions and second-class regions: some are very capable of managing investments and requesting funds and know perfectly which instruments are the most suitable for their interests; and others, secondly, have neither the knowledge nor the financial technical capacity to even request funds, let alone to manage them. And, worse still, they are second-rate regions that cannot access a large part of these funds, because from the European Union itself we impose austerity measures that burden the pockets of ordinary people and that terribly limit local administration, which is the closest to citizenship. That is why I think we need to pay more attention to reducing the differences between the various regions and the backwardness of the less-favored regions, which is what cohesion funds are for.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Dear Commissioner, Colleagues! Financial instruments, both in the previous and in the current financial perspective, showed their usefulness and good results. Nevertheless, their use is not without its problems and the potential is not fully realized. I believe that financial instruments are a good complement to grants as they are able to attract additional financial support where appropriate. Their added value should be appreciated especially in areas such as research and SMEs. However, I believe that also in the new financial perspective, grants should remain the basis of cohesion policy. They provide a proven and sound basis for public investment in infrastructure, environment and social investment. In order to find the most appropriate model for the combination of grants with loans and guarantees in the future, avoid a top-down uniform approach, but rather be flexible and allow local and regional authorities to choose the best form of support to offer based on local circumstances. And it is the local conditions and the specificity of individual regions that should be decisive as to the objectives of support for projects implemented under the cohesion policy. A Europe of the regions needs more trust. We must remember that it is those who implement these projects below, who build the potential of their cities, companies, regions and, ultimately, the European Union.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: - Mr President, the key challenge for the European Union today is deepening inequalities in the Union. That is why cohesion policy, which is a key tool in combating inequalities, is gaining new, even greater importance today. Mr Novakov's report rightly states that grants must retain their leading role in key public policies and that financial instruments could make a complementary contribution. Undoubtedly, efforts are needed to attract and combine private investment with public funds. However, there must be a clear distinction between the areas in which grants or financial instruments work best. However, when using the Structural and Investment Funds, the most important thing is to achieve cohesion goals. If a decisive policy in favor of cohesion is not adopted, it must be clear that a highly unbalanced Union has no future.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, EU cohesion funding has been vital for the north of Ireland and for border communities recovering from years of conflict and neglect. Now all of this good work is under threat because of a Brexit that most people in the north do not want and did not vote for. By supporting Brexit, the DUP has let the people of the north down, again, as we stand to lose EUR 982 million of much-needed and essential structural funding. This is funding for thousands of projects in the north of Ireland that people depend on for their businesses, for community projects and for infrastructure. Some projects are already being delayed because of the fears and uncertainties surrounding Brexit. It is hurting our communities now as you know, we spoke about this, and it will only get worse in the future if we do not have access to such cohesion funding and structural funding for the north, because we will see projects collapse.  Commissioner, the EU needs to ensure that the benefits of decades of cohesion funding for a community that has been emerging from conflict are not lost, by ensuring that the north is guaranteed ongoing access to cohesion funding in the future after Brexit, as part of us being afforded designated special status, or whatever it is called, within the EU.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Solidarity is a key value of the European Union and cohesion policy is a tool for putting this solidarity into practice. On the basis of cohesion policy, provinces in Ireland, Wales, Spain, Portugal, Greece and other Member States developed in the 1980s and 1990s. In this millennium, we, the new members, have had the opportunity to benefit from substantial cohesion funding. I myself was the mayor of a municipality with 25,000 people who benefited from more than 40 million European funds. Numerous water mains, sewage treatment plants, broadband connections on top of high hills are the result of cohesion policy. And if cohesion policy needs money and different resources, it also needs good, strong technical assistance. Technical assistance, with which we first train the state level, with which we get closer to local communities, the economy, science, research. And if in the previous financial period we had to conquer technology, how to build a large facility, now it is necessary to build knowledge, how to connect the economy, science, local communities, the country, and through smart specialization to bring new technologies, development, to individual countries. And that is what we are talking about today, so I strongly support these two reports, and I am convinced that cohesion policy must remain a cornerstone in the new financial perspective if we are to have the European Union.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs on their approach to such an important area as cohesion policy.The Union's cohesion policy has proved its worth, as it is indisputable proof of the European Union's ability to support its growth and recovery goals.In this financial year, as the Commissioner also pointed out, it is important that there is increased flexibility for beneficiaries through a wide range of instruments, as well as the fact that the private sector is involved in the form of co-investments or know-how.I also consider the involvement of the European Investment Bank in cohesion policy and, in particular, the support of national and local authorities to improve the quality of projects, as well as its contribution to attracting other investors to projects in disadvantaged regions by reducing risks.

name: Andor DELI
text: - President! I believe that profit-orientation should not play a disproportionate role in cohesion policy, because, for example, the return on investment and the success of investment in education or health cannot be measured solely in terms of benefits. Therefore, the mobilization of financial instruments is important, but in these areas they cannot trigger, but can only complement, grants. Experience to date has already shown that regions with persistently high unemployment and low population density have a very low investment attractiveness. And grants are precisely what helps regions in this situation to catch up. Therefore, when designing cohesion policy after 2020, it is important that the increase in the share of financial instruments does not lead to a decrease in the amount of grants, as this would hinder the achievement of the main objective of cohesion policy, the elimination of regional disparities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, grants and financial instruments, each with their own specificities, have generated tangible results for SMEs, for research, for the environment and for agriculture. However, much still needs to be done to optimize the use of resources available in all regions of Europe, it is necessary to eliminate the factors that discourage the use of financial instruments, i.e. reduce bureaucratic burdens, simplify access procedures, reduce costs. implementation and management fees. It is essential to make the rules governing the combination of different funds simpler, clearer and more transparent, and to encourage investment partnerships, so that Member States and regions are increasingly encouraged to take advantage of the tools available. The wide range of opportunities offered by the ESI Funds needs adequate advisory support in the form of technical assistance, which unfortunately, in some Member States, does not reach local and regional authorities sufficiently and effectively. It is essential to establish valid and transparent channels of communication in order to successfully implement the ESI Funds and to restore confidence in the effective functioning of the instruments made available by the European Union.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I congratulate my fellow rapporteurs, colleagues Novakova and Ruža Tomašić and greet the Commissioner.It is very important that cohesion policy, through financial instruments and technical assistance, is also at the service of citizens and entrepreneurs.So we have to listen to what they tell us, and they say that their financial instruments are quite complicated.Even the European Court of Auditors has said that the costs of managing financial instruments are very high.Our answer to that should be trust, not hundreds of pages of new instructions.So we need to focus more on outputs and less on input control and that’s what’s important to answer what they ask of us.Also, technical assistance must, of course, help strengthen management structures, but also end users, who need to be informed more about the possibilities of financing their ideas.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, firstly, we must not underestimate the negative impact of Brexit on deprived areas of the United Kingdom who benefit from ERDF and ESF regional development funding, particularly my region, the North-West of England, and specifically the rural area of Cumbria, but also Liverpool, which was regenerated with European money after Margaret Thatcher’s government decided to let it rot.  It is crucial that future cohesion policy is in line with sustainable development goals encompassing a broad range of objectives, not only oriented towards economic growth but promoting sustainable development of societies and individual and collective wellbeing of communities. Therefore, structural investment funds must be used for creative, innovative and smart initiatives that benefit a large part of the population, including the most vulnerable people. Although I welcome the important work done on urban agendas, I believe the specific needs and challenges of rural areas must continue to receive proper attention.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - In general, I would like to say about cohesion policy that it should be the backbone of the EU.Precisely because it expresses the principle of solidarity, ie.reducing disparities is a key EU policy.It must not be weakened by other instruments or neoliberal theories that cohesion policy is unnecessary.With regard to technical assistance, I would like to say that the report very rightly notes that those countries that have problems in drawing are also poorly drawing in the area of technical assistance.This should undoubtedly be considered by the Member States' authorities, which are mainly responsible for drawing.As far as the growth of the administration is concerned, it must be agreed that the growth of the administration in cohesion policy over the last few years is incredible and is also a production from the level of the European institutions.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, cohesion policy must be at the heart of the European Union's action. If we analyze the results obtained so far, only if we are not honest, we are not saying that we have benefited from cohesion policy. The purpose of the policy was from the very beginning established as a tool to develop the poorer areas, to reduce the differences in living standards of the citizens. We need to continue to provide cohesion funds and we need to avoid late payments to which farmers are entitled under the CAP. Commissioner, you have acted and supported cohesion policy and we thank you. We want you to support the creation of a multiregional investment platform for agriculture that is eligible for funding from the rural development program. We believe and I believe that we must not forget that there is a big difference between areas, regions of Europe in the field of infrastructure, transport, education, health. Solutions must be found for the cohesion funds to reach these areas. Thank you and we wish you success!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on putting this issue on the agenda. It is important to reiterate the importance of European cohesion policy and the role it has played in reducing development disparities and for the prosperity of the European Union. In this regard, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Corina Cretu again. Its efforts to make these investments more visible, but also to focus resources on key areas and objectives for Europe's development, have borne fruit and must continue to be supported. However, there are colleagues or political leaders who want cohesion policy to disappear by creating financial mechanisms in which social or geographical distribution criteria do not matter. We must not privatize cohesion policy, we must not hand over cohesion policy to financial-banking institutions, and in this respect, Commissioner, you have our full support. The revision of the multiannual financial framework or the future financial framework must not affect cohesion policy as it is a key instrument in the future development of the European Union. Thanks.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, thank you very much for this fruitful and very interesting debate. Thank you for your contributions. I really share your views that this policy is more important than ever, in times where we have so many divisions. I think it is very important to show solidarity between Member States, and this debate shows that together we can make this policy stronger. I would like to make some clarifications because I think there were some misunderstandings. I would like to underline that financial instruments do not lead to reallocation of funds between Member States or regions. When financial instruments are used, we do not support banks, we use them to transfer EU resources, with strict rules. Synergies are, of course, very important. I would like to thank Mr Lambert van Nistelrooij for [mentioning] this communications idea, a very elaborate document. I am very grateful to the Maltese Presidency that they also included in the Luxembourg meeting the Commission’s communications issue, on our debates between ministries for cohesion policy, because it is very important. I am very sorry that Mr Finch is not here any more because the irony of our policy is that this policy was created because of pressure by the UK, in 1975, when the United Kingdom said it would not go to the Council in Paris if this ERDF solidarity fund were not created, because there was the situation with the closure of mines, and it was the European funds, the ERDF solidarity fund, which retrained people in new activities. I am very sorry, but I don’t know if the people when voting for Brexit knew that they had jobs because of the European Union. Mr Finch is right. It is not European money, it is taxpayers' money, but this money is also going to the UK: in Liverpool, as you said, we now have the Metro in Cardiff ongoing and a lot of big projects, such as the university in Manchester . You mentioned the Peace program, which is very important. I am very worried, like you, about this because it was not London, it was not Belfast, it was not Dublin, but Brussels who put the money together for the reconciliation policy. I fully trust that Mr Barnier, our Chief Negotiator, will deal with that because this is a very important program and shows that this policy also has a role in healing the wounds that we have on the map of Europe. Thank you very much and I will now say a few words in my mother tongue. I believe that the two rapporteurs have played an important role in emphasizing the need to use both grants and financial instruments. Grants are practically very necessary when it comes to infrastructure, things, hospitals, schools, roads, which do not necessarily produce immediate profit, and financial instruments, Mr. Novakov, indeed, share your position, are just as indispensable, but we must to make sure that this combination is done in a suitable, calibrated, efficient manner. So I encourage all stakeholders, at national, regional and local level, managing authorities, banks - because they have the capacity and expertise to find that balance between grants and financial instruments. In that regard, the technical assistance that Mrs Tomašić talked about so much is very important. For this period, you are well aware that we in the European Commission have worked closely with the Member States to ensure that this funding period will bear fruit, but I do agree with you that we can do more. As for us, we encourage all Member States, help them to improve their administrative capacity, but also to establish the right legislation. As I told you at the beginning, we are trying to identify new priorities for technical assistance. My personal opinion and that of DG REGIO is that this technical assistance should be advanced at the beginning of the funding period in order to support the preparation of the programs in time, in order to avoid the delays we are now experiencing in the Member States, to facilitate the exchange of experience between regions and to join forces with the newly created Support Service for Structural Reforms, to work together on the ground.I look forward to our collaboration in the coming months for the debates on the post-2020 budget to ensure that the 500 million Europeans will benefit from the policy they deserve, to ensure a better life for them and their children., it is, I think, our responsibility as politicians and I assure you that I, personally, and my services will do everything we can to bring our input in this regard.Thank you very much.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: rapporteur. - I want to thank everyone who took part in the debate today. I am happy that there were also critical points of view. Along with them, however, we must say something. By the end of this programming period, almost half a trillion euros will be invested in European regions. Hundreds of millions are invested in European municipalities every day to solve people's problems. And these are facts that we cannot ignore. Of course there are problems to solve, of course there is room for improvement. Can we make procedures faster, easier and more understandable? Maybe. Can we make cohesion policy more visible? I guess you can. But here I support Commissioner Cretu, who says that cohesion policy reaches people, municipalities and regions more than any other European Union policy, and we must support this approach. Because every project implemented through the European Union, through the European Structural and Investment Funds, weakens the populists, and this is the qualitative difference between all constructive politicians and populists. The former deliver results, the latter only speak. I am sure that in the end people will appreciate what we have done and will judge us in our cases.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: author.- Mr. President, I would also like to thank everyone who took part in this debate.Special thanks to the shadow reporters.This actually shows, when we have a common goal that we can work very well together because so far this technical assistance has been like when someone sells you a washing machine and then two years later sends you instructions on how to use that machine.So now we have instructions, we have a machine, so let's go work.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - Cohesion Policy is a very important pillar of the EU, as it supports all regions and cities of the European Union and supports job creation, business competitiveness, economic growth, sustainable development and improving the quality of life of citizens . It is also a tangible example of European solidarity, as most cohesion policy funding is concentrated in less developed European countries and regions to help them catch up with other countries and reduce the economic, social and territorial disparities that persist. We support the Commission 's initiative for full funding of cohesion programs, combined with specialized technical assistance, as targeted technical assistance is a catalyst for the future of EU cohesion policy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The European Union, as a process of capitalist integration, is not oriented towards economic and social cohesion, but towards divergence. Cohesion policy, as such, only emerged when it was feared that the divergences created by free capitalist competition between economies with a very different degree of development would become unsustainable. However, the resources that have been devoted to it over the years have never allowed cohesion policy to do its job. Jacques Delors, more than twenty years ago, defended the doubling of the EU budget so that cohesion could be made effective. Since then, the EU has widened but the budget has shrunk. What was never enough was further weakened. Since the beginning of the century, Economic and Monetary Union and the Euro have given even more vigorous impetus to divergence. The structural funds - which now want to target speculation, to inflate “financial instruments” - assume, in this context, a central role. In addition to never being enough, their use has, over time, become increasingly conditioned, subject to the EU's political priorities and strategies (liberalization, privatization, deregulation) instead of targeting the specific needs of each country, according to its sovereign options.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - Financial instruments, which take the form of loans, guarantees, microcredit and private and venture capital, have become an integral part of the European Union's regional policy. While in the 2007-2013 programming period they represented only 6 percent of the volume of regional policy funds, in the period 2014-2020 their ratio is already 12 percent. Their need is indisputable. However, the need for grants is equally indisputable. Although today there are many opponents of direct funding from the European Union budget, which lacks the multiplier effects and thus a wider scope, it is not possible to say that we can replace grants with financial instruments. These are essential resources for the so-called smaller beneficiaries. In particular, projects in the fields of education, social affairs and employment promotion rely on the grant policy of the European budget. Therefore, we cannot afford to support large projects and beneficiaries at their expense, for which other financial mechanisms are more appropriate. The next few months and years represent an excellent opportunity to reflect on cohesion policy as the European Union's largest investment vehicle. We should therefore try to improve synergies between European budgetary instruments, including the very current European Fund for Strategic Investments, and in particular to improve the technical assistance advice that lagged behind in the previous programming period and to eliminate the time delays we are facing now. .

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - The most important role of cohesion policy is to close the gap between European regions. When establishing the sources of funding for cohesion policy and the relationship between them, we must not lose sight of this goal. Increasing the proportion of financial instruments in cohesion policy should in no way replace the current system of grants, as it would create an imbalance in public policies. It must be possible for each Member State to determine the ratio between financial instruments and grants, because there is no one-size-fits-all formula. It cannot be accepted that the Commission imposes the mandatory use of certain financial instruments. The more involved the national authorities are in the decision-making process, the better the results will be. There are states, such as Romania, that currently need grants and do not have the necessary capacity to replace them with financial instruments. The obligation of these states to use financial instruments in cohesion policy shows that, in fact, the Commission puts the financial interests of certain financial institutions and intermediaries above cohesion policy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - We are in the middle of the current seven-year programming period for drawing on the Structural and Investment Funds. That is why discussions are beginning to open up on what cohesion policy will look like after 2020. One of the key questions will be to what extent cohesion policy priorities will be funded by grants and to what extent we will use financial instruments. I support Mr Novakov's report because it also expresses my conviction that the grant system must be maintained in certain areas. Grants should be the preferred form of investment, especially in building public infrastructure, social services, but also research and innovation. Of course, Member States and regions must be left free to choose the share of grants and financial instruments in implementing their priorities. At the same time, I must say that the combination of these two types of tools still offers unexplored potential. I also agree with the view that financial instruments (such as various types of loans or guarantees) are important and effective, especially in developed regions and larger cities. But it must not be forgotten that remote regions, regions with high unemployment or low population density will always have difficulty attracting investment. It is precisely for these areas that are depopulating us that it will be necessary to keep the grant system in order to maintain a high level of education and social services there.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Almost thirty years after the entry into force of the European Single Act (EJA) on 1 July 1987, cohesion policy has played a key role in long-term economic growth in the less developed regions of the European Union. The anniversary is the right time for the European Parliament to assess the impact and role of the European Structural and Investment Funds. In the period from 2014 to 2020, the European Commission and the Member States have at their disposal EUR 14.6 billion of technical assistance under investment and technical funds. I believe that increasing funding for technical assistance is a prerequisite for all other economic activities and strategic investments. The establishment of efficient administrative and infrastructural conditions has an extremely favorable effect on the development of many economic branches. In order to preserve the transparency of the allocation of funds and take into account the regional level, it is necessary to involve and inform citizens, especially by using technical assistance at the national level to train local capacities. I am convinced that better coordination with existing technical assistance services, such as JASPERS, can contribute to flexibility in the allocation of funds, which is an appropriate course of action for various challenges, such as budgetary difficulties.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Cohesion policy is the EU's main branch of investment, providing citizens with added value, whether it is about creating new jobs or quality transport infrastructure. This policy has benefited all EU member states and has been an important support for countries such as Romania, especially during the economic crisis. It is true that the implementation of cohesion policy so far has not been perfect, and Member States still face difficulties in absorbing funds and developing quality projects. However, the benefits of these funds are obvious and hang heavier than the current impasse. That is why cohesion policy must remain a priority for Europe, so as not to further widen development gaps between regions. With regard to the future of cohesion policy, I wholeheartedly support the allocation of more funds and the prioritization of Central and Eastern European states in their redistribution, based on the principle of solidarity, so that imbalances can be corrected. Last but not least, the added value of this policy for the EU-citizens relationship is undeniable: by investing in key sectors, cohesion funds generate jobs and growth, thus meeting the needs of European citizens.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - The future of EU cohesion policy after 2020 must be decided through a transparent debate based on concrete arguments and realistic assessments. It is no exaggeration to say that this debate is an essential part of the wider debate on the future of the EU. European construction is based on solidarity, and a cohesive EU has no future. Effective implementation of cohesion policy is a precondition for the success of the Europe 2020 strategy. Smart, sustainable and inclusive growth is the EU's response to the challenges ahead. Reducing European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) by offering the alternative of using the European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan) is not an acceptable solution because only cohesion funds ensure a fair, balanced territorial distribution that takes into account the development of the regions involved. Cohesion policy grants address the issue of regional structural disparities and allow the EU to maintain a balanced regional funding policy. Unfortunately, the danger looms both over the future of cohesion policy after 2020 and over the implementation of these policies starting in 2019, the likely year of Brexit. The European Parliament must express its clear and strong support for maintaining cohesion policy as a cornerstone of European solidarity and the future of the EU.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Zambia. As I have said already, we are behind schedule as this House does not always have the best of discipline before the vote.
