I would like to keep to the schedule and be on time so that we are able to hear the closing remarks at the end of the debate on the urgent issues.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, Zambia is one of the few countries in Africa that have seen more than two peaceful transfers of power: one of the continent’s democratic success stories since moving to multi—party elections in 1991. The close elections last year, which saw incumbent President Lungu narrowly beat the opposition party leader Hakainde Hichilema, has the potential to jeopardise that success. Concerns were first raised after the Constitutional Court quickly dismissed Hichilema’s electoral petition, with events coming to a head after the bizarre arrest of Hichilema on charges of treason. In response, the influential Zambia Conference of Catholic Bishops issued a strongly-worded letter claiming that the country had become a dictatorship in all but name. Despite Zambia’s overall success, this is not the first time that a President there has sought to consolidate his power, as was seen by the former President Chiluba’s unsuccessful attempts to secure an unconstitutional third term in 2001. We must now support the EU’s efforts to see tensions relieved and ensure that Zambia and its democratic constitution is upheld and supported by the European Union.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Hakainde Hichilema, leader of the opposition, was arrested on charges of treason as his convoy obstructed the passage of President Lungu's, while both were on the same road. It sounds incredible, and yet it really happened. To this point, in order to eliminate or limit the political opposition in Zambia and, as if that were not enough, some of his collaborators, also placed under arrest, were subjected to torture of various kinds. The strength and quality of a government also lie in allowing criticism and dissent, if we want to grow and reach the elaboration of policies that bring progress and development for the country. Hichilema and all those arrested with him must be released immediately, also considering the recent sentence of acquittal for injury. At the same time, an investigation must be opened aimed at verifying whether there really have been human rights violations against those arrested and, if so, prosecuting the perpetrators. In light of the recent cooperation agreements, I believe it is necessary for the European Union to use economic leverage vis-à-vis the Edgar Lungu government until there is full respect for the rights of the opposition and human rights.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, Zambia has for many years been one of the more promising countries on the African continent. The country has two peaceful transfers of powers, making it unusual in Africa. But in the last months there has been a serious backsliding. Zambia is now, as the important national body Conference of Catholic Bishops noted in an unusually strongly-worded criticism of the government, ‘all except in designation a dictatorship’. The leader of the opposition, Hakainde Hichilema, has been arrested on trumped-up charges. The government accuses him of treason but has not presented a shred of evidence against him. Mr Hichilema’s arrest is just the tip of the iceberg – civil society is attacked, the judiciary and police is politicised. The political pressure needs to be upped. We need to start considering Zambia as a country heading for dictatorship. President Lungu needs to know that we are watching him.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: author. - Mr President, considering the current situation in the country, we want to call on the Government and the opposition to initiate a peaceful and constructive dialogue to overcome the current political tensions and to focus on solving the serious socio-economic problems that affect the Zambian people. Just a few facts: the rural poverty rate in Zambia in 2015 was 76.6%, which is three times urban poverty, and almost no decline has been observed between 2010 and 2015. Malnutrition is estimated to be a factor. underlying 54% of infant deaths. Large numbers of people do not have access to safe water and adequate sanitation services. And HIV and AIDS are pandemic in the country. That is why we also ask the Government to respect, protect and promote the civil and political rights of its citizens; to guarantee a fair trial for Hakainde Hichilema in accordance with the African Charter and other international and regional human rights instruments, as well as to end repressive and discriminatory practices against LGBTI people.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: author. - Mr Chairman! I would like to begin by thanking the other political groups for their good cooperation and for preparing a joint motion for a resolution. Since the 2016 election campaign and elections, as everyone knows, political tension has been growing between the ruling party and the opposition party in Zambia, a country that has undergone many peaceful pro-democracy changes over the past 25 years. As everyone has been saying, as a consequence Hakainde Hichilema, the main leader of the opposition party, who did not recognize President Lungu's election victory, was arrested, imprisoned and charged with high treason. It is a crime for which the maximum sentence in Zambia is the death penalty. As we know, no execution has been carried out in this country for 20 years, but so far such the highest penalty is still possible in Zambia for a crime defined as high treason. As we have also noted numerous reports of political motivation in relation to the charges against Hichilem, and given that the trial will start as early as this week, I would like to call for an urgent political dialogue between the two parties with the support of international partners, including the European Union and regional organizations. The Zambian government must get Hichilema to a fair trial.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: Author.- Mr President, the fight against fundamental rights violations, such as the one taking place in Zambia, involves two orders of measures.Firstly, it is necessary to strengthen the powers and competences of the International Criminal Court and to broaden its area of activity, even to countries that have not signed the Treaty of Rome.The certainty that no humanitarian law violator will go unpunished is the greatest guarantee that we can give to potential victims of these violations, because it is the greatest deterrent that we can impose on violators.Other measures are of a political and economic nature and require a genuine and determined fight against poverty.Where there is poverty, there will always be violations of human rights, not least because poverty is, in itself, a qualified violation of humanitarian law.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr President, the Group of the European People's Party was the initiator of the debate on Zambia.The country's political climate has been marked by tensions since last summer's presidential election.The arrest of opposition leader Hichilema exacerbates the political crisis.The circumstances that led to his arrest are bizarre.Hichilema is accused of treason and risks being sentenced to death for a minor road accident: he allegedly obstructed the presidential convoy.In fact, President Lungu is unhappy because his opponent in last year's election challenged the result of the competition.I ask the Zambian authorities to remain within the limits of democracy, the absurd revenge solves absolutely nothing, as other colleagues have said, the healthy solution is a dialogue between power and opposition.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have had the opportunity to lead the European Union Election Observation Mission in Zambia. I take this opportunity once again to thank the High Representative for Foreign Policy, Federica Mogherini, for the trust placed in me. I do not deny it, we have encountered some difficulties in the electoral process, dictated by the limitation of freedom of expression, by access to the media, by the low participation of women, by the functioning of the Constitutional Court for appeals. However, the result was objective, the outgoing president reported a narrow majority on the opposition candidate. With this resolution, Parliament recognizes the efforts of the Zambian people and government. The release, after a fair trial, of the defeated candidate Hakainde Hichilema will be an extraordinary opportunity to confirm the progress made in recent decades in terms of governance and political alternation, as well as to be an example of democratic consolidation also for the other countries of the continent African.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Dear colleagues, of course we must be concerned about the human rights situation and I find that we are doing useful work. Nevertheless, I am wondering. Undermining state security and treason are matters that we have seen at home too, as is the use of politics and even the notion of state security, whether in states. United or in France. This notion has been used to destabilize politicians. Second, we act in the name of our values. But our values ​​are called into question because, by this double standard, it is very easy to accuse others. What do we do with us? Then, as if by chance, we are the only ones. China, India and other big countries are under no obligation to intervene in everything. As for Zambia, like many African states, it faces intractable contradictions. It must manage its rural exodus, its modernization and democratization, which is so difficult, especially since it is in a situation of international competition which prevents the constitution of its own economic fabric and it is under IMF surveillance. Zambia is therefore one of those states tossed about by the markets and under surveillance by the West. The best action we can do for this country is to let the Bishops' Conference and the African Union act together to find solutions and support those solutions, according to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, five weeks ago the Zambian opposition leader, Hakainde Hichilema, was brutally detained in his home while he was sleeping, accused of treason. This serious episode and the protests it gave rise to are the culmination of the restrictions on freedom of expression and the increase in police and political violence that have been occurring in Zambia since the presidential election campaign in August last year. The disproportionate and unnecessary violence used by police forces at the time of his arrest, the conditions in which he is detained and the possibility of incurring a life sentence or even the death penalty constitute a threat to the rule of law and clearly violate international obligations of Zambia. The European Union must clearly condemn all forms of intimidation against those whom the Government considers to be opponents and support the promotion of an open and constructive dialogue between the Patriotic Front and the United Party for national development that allows the rescue of democracy in Zambia.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the general situation in Zambia should be closely monitored and the resolution provides for this. A peaceful and constructive dialogue must be initiated urgently.I welcome the involvement of international and regional partners in the democratization of Zambia.I visited this country and saw people living in poverty, but also with the fear of tomorrow.There are people there too, and if we want to be truly supportive, we should work with other European and global institutions to democratize, but also to eradicate poverty.We must not forget that there is still the death penalty, which is unacceptable.There are many restrictions on freedom of expression and freedom of association that can lead to conflict, so it is good to implement this resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Zambia is a poor African country, which is really facing a huge problem due to the spread of AIDS. The clashes between the government and the opposition are due to the questioning of the results of the presidential elections in August 2016, when President Lungu won by a very small margin. Thus, the challenge on the part of Hitsilema, the leader of the opposition, has led to conflicts, the leader of the opposition has been arrested and even his life is in danger. It is obvious that there must be a compromise between the government and the opposition. I think that the European Union, the Commission, must play an important role in this, in order to restore calm in the region, so that the two warring forces can find a solution, because the predominant problem in Zambia is poverty. This is what they need to see and based on this guide to resolve their differences.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, can one be accused of treason for blocking a presidential march? Apparently, in Zambia, unfortunately yes. Opposition leader Hakainde Hichilema, who was the current president's main challenger at the last presidential lectures, was arrested along with many of his collaborators and we have even seen the treason allegations backdated to a previous arrest, when he went to jail. to visit some supporters. The Union Election Observation Mission also highlighted the serious irregularities that would have taken place during the last elections, thus acknowledging the opposition that they are not completely wrong in denouncing a series of problems and, among other things, we have not not even had the possibility to monitor the final aggregation of the results during their sending to the national center. We ask that Zambia fully respect the Cotonou agreements, free Hakainde Hichilema and his collaborators and, above all, stop this farcical trial for which they would even risk the death penalty. Torture, ill-treatment and political persecution are not acceptable under any circumstances and we must also remember that those 484 million euros cannot be disbursed otherwise.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would especially like to thank the authors of this resolution because it draws our attention to the problem of a poor country where we thought some progress has already been made.As it turns out, the progress is very fragile, and the arrest of an opposition leader is something that could only happen on the basis of indisputable evidence.The case itself is very embarrassing, it is raising big questions.Torture the collaborators of the arrested opposition leader are, in my opinion, completely inadmissible acts.Zambia will now face a test of its justice, whether it has also succumbed to state pressure, whether it is truly independent and impartial.It is in our vital interest to monitor this process as to whether it will fulfill all the attributes of a fair trial and whether Zambia has not really slipped out of the progress that has been made and slipped into its original tracks.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for this timely debate on the developments in Zambia, which deserve our attention.  The European Union values highly its partnership with Zambia. We are proud of our significant contribution to that country’s development and are firmly committed to remaining a key partner. The European Union is also aware of the various challenges the country is facing and supports its ambitious economic and governance reform agenda.  You may recall the EU’s involvement, through the deployment of an EU election observation mission, led by the honourable Member Cécile Kyenge, who has just taken the floor. We are very grateful for the work she has done. We are advocating implementation of the mission’s recommendations, in particular in response to its concerns relating to freedom of expression and assembly.  Zambia has traditionally been a peaceful and democratic nation in a neighbourhood so often marked by political instability and human rights violations. It is therefore of even greater concern that Zambia’s democratic trajectory is being questioned, particularly since the highly—contested elections in August 2016, which revealed the polarised nature of the country. The arrest of the opposition leader, Hakainde Hichilema, on 11 April resulted in increased political tensions, to which the European Union was quick to respond by calling on all parties to refrain from any action or rhetoric likely to aggravate the situation. The European Union, in close coordination with the Member States, will further convey a strong message to both the government and the opposition to play a constructive role and to engage in a dialogue to restore trust in support of an inclusive political environment.  Regarding the ongoing proceedings against Mr Hichilema, the European Union calls upon the government of Zambia to ensure transparency, independence of the judiciary and the right to a fair trial and due process, according to international human rights law. Making Zambia’s institutions accountable and inclusive is vital for upholding its democratic credentials and political stability. The European Union will continue to engage with our Zambian partners through all political and diplomatic means, at all levels, calling upon the wisdom and sense of responsibility of all parties to avoid further reputational damage to Zambia’s strong democratic traditions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - We voted in favor of the resolution as it expresses its concern over the arrest and imprisonment of Hakaide Hitsilema and insists on the need to ensure impartiality, diligence and transparency at all stages of law enforcement and throughout the judicial process. It also notes with concern the reports that the allegations are politically motivated and therefore recalls the need to respect fundamental rights and the rule of law, including access to justice and the right to a fair trial, such as provided for in the African Charter, and in other international and regional human rights instruments.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Ethiopia, notably the case of Dr Merera Gudina.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, as host of the African Union and a key regional contributor to UN peace missions, Ethiopia’s role is strategic. With conflicts in neighbouring South Sudan and Somalia, in addition to the repressive regime of Afwerki in Eritrea to its north, Ethiopia has found itself host to the largest refugee population in Africa. For one of the poorest countries in the world by GDP per capita, such responsibilities place great strain on the country’s resources. I hope therefore that today’s resolution can be seen in a constructive manner, reminding Ethiopia’s government that the EU is here to support its actions but that fundamental human rights to free speech and a right to peaceful protest must still be upheld. I welcome the calls in the resolution for a UN-led inquiry into the heavy-handed actions taken by the government in response to the protests in Oromia state. This, along with the release of political prisoners including Dr Gudina, will be vital to improving Ethiopia’s record of enforcing the rule of law and democracy – a key part also of honouring its obligations under the EU’s Cotonou agreement.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about Ethiopia we are talking about a key country in the balance of sub-Saharan Africa, a signatory to the Cotonou Agreement which, unfortunately, is denying it with its actions. Following a hearing organized by Mrs Ana Gomes, whom I greet, some opposition leaders, including Merera Gudina, were arrested simply for attending this hearing and charged with lobbying the government and threatening society, even through violence, disturbing the constitutional order. They have no right to defense and have been charged with four violations of the criminal code. Unfortunately, human rights violations still occur in Ethiopia, there is excessive use of force against Oromo and other ethnic groups and, at the same time, the government is abusing the anti-terrorism law against anyone who criticizes it, attacking journalists, bloggers and protesters. Because of its importance in the region, we demand the release of all political prisoners, including Merera Gudina, Berhanu Nega and Jawar Mohammed, and a truly international and independent investigation that clarifies all human rights violations, we cannot allow them anymore. .

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: author. – Mr President, Ethiopia is a key partner and a hope for economic improvement and political stability in a troubled region, but the truth is also that the country’s regime is authoritarian, cracking down mercilessly on those who voice dissent. Economic growth and enforced political stability are prioritised at the expense of human rights and civil liberties, and especially the fundamental rights of the country’s unrepresented groups are being violated on a daily basis. Most of these groups are systematically marginalised by the central government. Those living in the Ogaden and Oromia regions are most vulnerable to the persecution, as the case of Dr Gudina and others show. There is a need for greater ethnically-diverse democratic participation and more equal access to political, economic, social and cultural opportunities among the different groups. Being aware of the importance of Ethiopia for the economic and political stability of the region should not relieve us from the moral obligation of addressing and denouncing the severe human rights violations still taking place there.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, a decade of strong development in Ethiopia has lifted many out of poverty, of which it can be proud, but now this is all at risk. Ethiopia is in its eighth month of emergency rule. The government is systematically repressing freedom. In November, the leader of the opposition, Professor Merera Gudina was detained shortly after arriving in Addis Ababa from Brussels, where he gave a speech in this House. Independent media and civil society are also under attack. If the Ethiopian government values its long-standing cooperation with the EU and the great achievements of Ethiopia, it has to start respecting its own constitution. The government needs to immediately end emergency rule and let the United Nations in to visit political prisoners. Crucially, it needs to immediately release Professor Merera Gudina from prison.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Mr. President, Ethiopia is a great country, rich in its history and in the diversity of its people. It is a key country in the region, which has many friends, including in this forum. But respecting a friend is knowing how to tell them things; Today in particular, with the arrest of Dr Merera Gudina, on his return from Europe, where he came to testify, here, on the situation of the Oromos, we cannot be silent. All the more so when we are told that EU-Ethiopia relations could suffer from our vote, especially in the area of ​​migration. This is called blackmail. For several months, the situation has deteriorated, especially since the implementation of the state of emergency. We are talking about 26,000 arrests, hundreds of deaths - more than six hundred, according to an official report -, torture in prisons. We cannot be silent. The Ethiopian authorities must be called on to shed light on what they call allegations, to agree to an international investigation and to release the political prisoners arrested in the name of the fight against terrorism, which has a good back.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, there is no doubt about EU sympathy towards Ethiopia. Only 11 months ago, EU-Ethiopia strategic engagement agreement was signed, recognising the crucial role of Ethiopia in Africa, especially for providing stability for the region of the Horn of Africa. Ethiopia also has generously received almost one million refugees from neighbouring countries. However, today we are very much worried that the leader of the opposition party, Dr Merera Gudina, has been under arrest for almost half a year. Ironically, following his visit to the European Parliament, he is accused of creating pressure against the government – that is the opposition’s constitutional role – and so disrupting the constitutional order. Sadly, Dr Gudina is not alone. Our resolution lists several names – journalists, one-line activists – who are kept in detention. Today, therefore, we strongly urge the Ethiopian government to release immediately Dr Gudina and all other political prisoners; to allow international investigation on the killings of protesters on government-sponsored land grabs; to start genuine dialogue with the opposition, which is the only way toward a more democratic society; to stop using anti-terrorist laws and a state of emergency to suppress peaceful protests and dissent; and to provide unrestricted access for human rights organisations and NGOs to all parts of the country. These are also criteria for meaningful and credible implementation of our strategic engagement agreement.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, Ethiopia is one of the poorest countries in the world and the people suffer from drought and other dire challenges that leave millions hungry and dependent on aid. It is important that the EU cooperate to help people and save lives, but it would be a grave mistake only to look at the challenges of people in Ethiopia through the lens of ‘managing migration’ and not to address the dire human rights violations which risk being overshadowed. Counter—terrorism laws are being abused, critics are being silenced and farmland has been expropriated. Hundreds of people were killed last month, according to Ethiopia’s Human Rights Commission itself. However, human rights organisations and NGOs claim that even more people were killed in demonstrations. Today we call on the government of Ethiopia to respect the rights to freedom of expression, including the press freedom of critics, to lift the remaining elements of the state of emergency, and especially to give access to aid organisations for all areas and all people who are in need of assistance. It is important that political prisoners, journalists and human rights defenders be freed from detention and for the Ethiopian Government to adhere to its own commitments made under the African Charter, in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, towards democracy and respecting human rights.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! Ethiopia plays a key role in ensuring the security of the Horn of Africa, and dealing with drought disasters, epidemics, and the influx of refugees and flows, it carries enormous burdens on its shoulders. It is important to solve all these problems in a way that respects law and democracy, also on the basis of the recently concluded cooperation agreement with the European Union. Meanwhile, the Ethiopian authorities have repeatedly used force against the opposition, suppressing peaceful demonstrations, committing acts of persecution, arbitrary arrests and killings against ethnic minorities, journalists, bloggers and political activists. We therefore call on the Ethiopian government to release bail and drop the charges against Dr Merer Gudina and the remaining political prisoners, and to urge representatives of the European Union to take steps to launch an international investigation under the aegis of the United Nations into the killing of demonstrators.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in Ethiopia two days ago Yonatan Tesfaye, spokesperson for the opposition Blue Party, was sentenced as a terrorist for comments he made on Facebook about human rights. Last November, Dr Merera Gudina, the Oromo opposition leader, was arrested and tortured under terrorist charges for the crime of participating in a public hearing here, at the European Parliament, with Dr Berhanu Negra, another opposition leader democratically elected in 2005, then sent to jail, now in exile, and also deemed a terrorist. Thousands of political prisoners languish in jail in Ethiopia, jailed by a totalitarian government which was never elected, and whose last farcical election emulated North Korea, with the ruling party winning 100% of the votes. The violation of human rights in Ethiopia is systematic and aggravated under the state of emergency, with excessive force against peaceful demonstrators, massacres like at Irreecha, brutalising victims of the garbage dump landslide last March, brutal repression against the Roma community and other ethnic groups, arbitrary arrests, torture, killings, and terrorist charges against those who dare to dissent.  In this resolution we call on the High Representative to mobilise members to support a UN-led inquiry into the killings in Ethiopia. The Commission and Council must stop the pretence that they are dealing with a respectful government in Ethiopia as justification for wasting piles of EU taxpayers’ money on development aid, security capacity and the migration compact. They are, in fact, assisting a corrupt dictatorship which rules by terror, thus fuelling rebellion and insecurity. Ethiopia is indeed strategic. When Ethiopians revolt all Africa will tremble.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! Yesterday, we voted in favor of the Commission's proposal to add Ethiopia to the EU's list of high-risk countries, for e.g. corruption and money laundering. I want to tell you about the case of Fikru Maru, who is a Swedish doctor who in 2006 started a heart hospital in Addis Ababa. In 2010, he was accused of trying to smuggle in hospital materials, when he refused to pay a bribe. The charges were dropped and he was released. In May 2013, he was arrested for the incident in 2010 due to corruption allegations against Ethiopia's customs minister. After three and a half years in prison in Kaliti, he was convicted of knowledge of corruption at ministerial level. He was sentenced to four years and eight months in prison in addition to a fine. In September 2016, he was accused of being behind the riot in the prison, and thus a terrorist crime, which includes the death penalty in the penalty scale, despite the fact that he was at the same time in hospital for treatment of a collapsed lung. The interrogation of witnesses was subsequently annulled in the Supreme Court of Ethiopia, but on May 11, it was four years ago that Fikru Maru was imprisoned and he is still not free.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Ethiopia is fragile.It is one of the African countries experiencing the greatest economic growth, but remains extremely poor.Its security situation is deteriorating, particularly with regard to relations between the majority ethnic group and other ethnic groups.In this context, it is important to see that fundamental rights are effectively guaranteed.Of course, we have a role of vigilance on human rights, but we also try to look at home first.Africa has its own multilateral institutions.Does she need our lessons on opposition rights?African countries have their own path to democracy.Let us strengthen the power of the African Union, which will, I hope, cope with this complexity.We are not mandated by the United Nations to organize this gendarme of human rights.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! The human rights situation in Ethiopia concerns us continuously in this House. Human rights officer Stavros Lambrinidis also expressed concern after his last visit. Contrary to official assurances, the Ethiopian government is making no move to deviate from its restrictive course. A particular affront was the arrest of Dr. Godina, immediately after his appearance here in the European Parliament. With this course the Ethiopian government is harming itself. It is endangering the not inconsiderable funds for development cooperation. And why should such a policy be rewarded? By jeopardizing these resources, it is also jeopardizing the country's economic boom that is emerging. It cannot be stressed enough: the restriction of human rights and the elimination of democratic structures never create stability. On the contrary, they endanger stability, and this must be borne in mind in view of the dramatic situation in the Horn of Africa with millions of refugees.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the case of Dr Merera Gudina offers a worrisome insight into the state of freedom of expression, association, and assembly in Ethiopia. I therefore strongly support calls on the Ethiopian authorities to prevent ethnic, religious or political discrimination and to encourage and act in favour of a peaceful and constructive dialogue between all communities. I also wish to remind the Ethiopian Government of their obligations to guarantee fundamental rights, including access to justice and the right to a fair trial, as provided for in the African Charter. There can be no denying that the political, economic and democratic stability of Ethiopia is crucial to the development of the countries of the Horn of Africa. We must therefore remain dedicated to the fostering of a healthy working relationship between the EU and the Ethiopian Government in order to advance democratic values in this state. We have got to keep working and we intend to do so.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I am very glad to see the issue of human rights in Ethiopia brought to this agenda. However, I am deeply concerned that the resolution bears no mention of the systematic and widespread sexual violence against women as part of the persecution of ethnic minorities in Ethiopia. We have had testimonies in this Parliament from victims, survivors and civil society activists. We heard of mass rape and torture in prisons and camps, we heard of systematic abuse to break up Ogaden and Oromo communities. These are horrifying crimes, taking place far away from the cameras and the gaze of the world’s media. All of us here must give voice to the voiceless and issue a strong call to the Ethiopian Government to stop these atrocities immediately, investigate reports and bring the perpetrators to justice.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr. President, a state of emergency can in no way mean the imprisonment of political opponents. It is not through violence and terror that problems will be solved. Whatever the strategic situation of states, the European Union cannot allow democratic systems to be violated. When Dr Merera Gudina came to testify here, before this Parliament, about the situation in his country, he did nothing but his duty and can in no way be condemned for it, quite the contrary. In the European Parliament, we must constantly remind ourselves that a democratic country must be characterized by respect for democratically established rights, in particular the right to express the opposition, and by the existence of independent justice. Everywhere, especially with partner states, we must demand that democracy and freedoms of expression be guaranteed, as well as all human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Ethiopia is an important country for the Horn of Africa, it can really play an even more important role. It has signed an agreement with the European Union, of course it is also bound by the Cotonou agreement, but apparently the situation has gone away, because we now have a state of emergency, we have prisons, we have arrests of the opposition, we have land grabbing, we have a situation which is now inadmissible. They do not respect freedom of expression, nor the freedom of the press, and of course they arrest journalists and bloggers. I think a decisive message must be sent to the Ethiopian government that the situation is no longer going well and that it must now abide by what has been agreed and, of course, protect human rights.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, of course, the European Union watches with great concern the difficult domestic situation in Ethiopia and follows closely reports of human rights violations. Ethiopia faces multiple challenges and a deteriorating humanitarian situation, including several droughts and a cholera outbreak, but also persisting pockets of violence throughout the country. The European Union is aware of the difficult situation that the Oromo People’s Congress and other key opposition parties face and has repeatedly highlighted these concerns to the government. The EU delegation in Ethiopia closely follows the case of Dr Merera. They attend his trials and have regular contact with his lawyers. The delegation equally monitors trials of other opposition leaders detained and has regular contacts with their remaining leadership. The situation has further deteriorated under the state of emergency, and the stability of the country and of the wider region remains at serious risk. Ethiopia is an important partner, and the situation warrants the EU’s close attention. The EU-Ethiopia Strategic Engagement is the right framework to address and follow issues of concern. The visit of High Representative Mrs Mogherini to Addis Ababa in March was an opportunity to discuss political developments with the Prime Minister, emphasising the imperative to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms under the state of emergency as well as for a credible political dialogue with the opposition. She reiterated him again in the margins of the Somalia conference in London, and he was grateful for the EU’s continuous engagement. It is important to note that the first dialogue at the EU-Ethiopia Strategic Engagement was the governance and human rights sectoral dialogue. It was formally launched in the presence of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, during his visit to Addis Ababa from 4 to 6 April. Topics discussed included due process of law and detention conditions; youth empowerment and children’s rights, including female genital mutilation; and migrants’ rights. We are now working on concrete follow-up, in particular on the strengthening of independent civil society, the establishment of a strong political dialogue, and the improvement of conditions in detention centres. Since this visit, the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission has reported to the Parliament on its findings on the violence that led to the current state of emergency. We welcomed the recommendation that security personnel responsible for the excessive use of force should be held accountable. We have encouraged the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission to work with the independent civil society organisations and human rights defenders and to publicly share all of their reports. We also welcome the recent visit of UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mr Al Hussein, to the country and strongly encourage Ethiopia to cooperate with UN special procedures. The EU continues to stress the need to address guidance of the population and encourage tangible changes to laws and practices to ensure more outlets for citizens to express their views and concerns freely and peacefully, including through independent media, political parties and civil society. The arrest of senior leaders of the opposition such as Dr Merera is detrimental to a process of reconciliation and dialogue. We have called for the release of the leaders of the opposition and supported calls for independent investigations into all acts of violence. The European Union stands ready to work together in addressing these issues. Given the enormous task that the country is facing in terms of humanitarian challenges and its key role in issues of common concerns – regional peace and security, migration, climate change – we must be ready to support them to foster democracy and prosperity and we think that one cannot exist without the other.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: written.Ethiopia is an important political ally of the EU and many other Western countries.The country plays a key role in the African Union and is an important partner on numerous UN security missions.The country is not doing badly economically either.With an average growth of 10%, it is one of the fastest growing economies in Africa.Yet it is not all gold that shines.Besides drought and poverty, the country is also struggling with a government that ignores basic democratic principles.For example, the Ethiopian government is all too readily accusing activists, journalists and bloggers of terrorism, protests by the Oromo minority are brutally crushed and the declaration of a state of emergency is being abused to silence opposition members.That is why the N-VA delegation supports the present resolution calling on the Ethiopian government to release Merera Gudina and all other political prisoners and restore the rule of law.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on South Sudan.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, South Sudan is collapsing. The civil war has brought the country to its knees and now there is a serious risk that the conflict will take on a full ethnic dimension and could lead to genocide. Almost half of the population do not have enough food. If not bullets, then malnutrition and starvation will kill them. Humanitarian workers are blocked because the danger is great and there are too many difficulties, which means that they cannot assist the population affected and anyone who urgently needs help.  The conflict cannot be solved militarily. We must immediately declare a ceasefire that brings together all the actors, and not just the parties in conflict, in order to recognise that the country has suffered enough and that the next steps are those of reconciliation and reconstruction.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Author. - Exactly a week ago in my country, the Netherlands, a remarkable opinion article about South Sudan was published, for this article was entitled: "Despair and hope in South Sudan". What a contradiction! Despair, human despair among the people of South Sudan is completely conceivable. Our joint resolution identifies the atrocities of war to which South Sudanese have long been exposed. However, in this almost hopeless situation, is there still hope in and for South Sudan? Hell yes! Well-thought-out local initiatives are now bearing fruit - we must not forget that - give hope. I quote: If a girl can go to school - and that is what happens in South Sudan -, is not married off - and it is - and is treated with more respect, that is a great gain for her now and later. It gives herself hope for her own future and hope for her own country of South Sudan. I sincerely hope that, thanks to European support, many more signs of such hope in torn, parched, starving South Sudan will be realized with our help.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: author. – Mr President, the situation in South Sudan is a nightmare. Civil war, appalling human rights violations and under-development have caused huge suffering to the population and have forced millions of its citizens to flee. Famine has been declared in some regions, and particularly worrying is the situation for the children. They make up 62% of the refugees and 17 000 have been used as child soldiers. Arms trafficking is fuelling the tragedy, and the UN report gives details about arms trafficking networks within the European Union. This is a clear violation of the EU common position on exports of arms and dual use goods. This is outrageous, and I appeal to the Member States concerned to fully take their responsibilities. The EU is a major humanitarian and aid contribution to South Sudan, but the laxness of at least one of our Member States when it comes to arms exports counteracts all these efforts.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, the women and children of South Sudan cannot stand here today to express their desperation, so we must speak up for them. Women and girls are systematically raped and abducted as a weapon of war. A UN survey has found that 70% of women living in IDP camps in Juba have been raped, the vast majority by police or soldiers. Tens of thousands of children are believed to have been recruited by armed groups. By the end of 2017, half of the country’s population will have been displaced or perished. The country is facing famine and economic collapse. President Salva Kiir and former Vice—President Riek Machar must respect their obligations. President Kiir has committed to unilateral ceasefire; he must implement it and must immediately bring the rapists and murderers among the police and military to justice.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: author. - Mr. President, since 2013 South Sudan has plunged into an ethnic civil war, and, according to the UN, the conflict has generated three and a half million displaced people, of which two million are children. Furthermore, the worst drought in the country's history has left two out of three Sudanese in grave danger of famine. But the terrible scenario carved out by repression, ethnic violence and cuts in freedoms, as well as the effects of climate change, is of human origin. It is unacceptable that our foreign action does nothing more than contribute to the problem. It is shameful that our aid policy responds solely to our ill-advised geostrategic interests, completely obviating the needs of the Sudanese and reinforcing the legitimacy of a criminal government. The Khartoum process is one such example, allocating development aid to outsource border control, adorning it with beautiful human rights rhetoric. For this reason, the role of the European Union should go through establishing aid channels guided by criteria of effectiveness and not a conditionality linked to collaboration in migration policy, such as border flow control.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. - I would like to start by thanking all the political groups. It is not very often in this room that the political groups really agree in unanimity on this relatively important and relatively important text. I think it is important to seek unity. It is important to find consistency with the regime in South Sudan. What is happening in Sudan is, of course, a complete disaster, with 40% of people not having access to food every day. Many women, as has already been mentioned here by my predecessors, have been raped. Many children are used as child soldiers. We cannot just look at what is happening in South Sudan with impunity. That is why we want to call on all EU governments, and especially those national governments that have had their own interests there in the past, to really start doing something about this situation. It is not possible for us to just look at the humanitarian catastrophe and the suffering of many people. It is absolutely scandalous that we cannot actually guarantee the safety of humanitarian workers. Many humanitarian workers have been killed or abducted in recent months. It is therefore necessary to call once again on the Member States and other states of the democratic community to work for the restoration of order and law in Sudan. To respect at least some elements of the UN International Covenant on Human Rights. Otherwise, those generations that will bear the consequences will have a terrible experience, and it will be a terrible experience to know that we are to blame.

name: Javier NART
text: Author. - Mr President, one is quite bored with the rhetorical condemnations on which we all agree so as not to arrive at anything other than to calm our own conscience, sometimes our own hypocrisy. Sudan is a tragedy that is carried out by men. It is an ethnocide created by mankind, specifically by the two leaders (the Nuer and the Dinka), Salva Kiir and Riek Machar. We have to establish a ceasefire first. Second, the presence of real interposition troops. Active troops, not the MONUSCO scandal in the Congo, that is, "tourist soldiers." Truly interposing forces in the face of the tragedy of the Congolese people. Third, thanks to this, humanitarian aid can arrive. And finally, establish a criminal court that brings criminals, ethnocidalists, who are the leaders of South Sudan to that court. The ruling leader and the opposition. And, of course, freeze their assets abroad - in European banks! -, which are a consequence of corruption.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, is dóigh liom gurb é seo an tríú nó an ceathrú huair go bhfuilimid ag déanamh díospóireachta anseo faoin tSúdáin Theas ó bunaíodh an tír thall ansin. Ach in ionad rudaí a bheith ag éirí níos fearr, tá siad ag éirí níos measa agus an chúis ná an cogadh cathartha – an cogadh is measa. Mar i gcogadh cathartha déanann daoine scrios ar a dtír féin agus tá scrios déanta acu sa tSúdáin Theas.  Tá na daoine ag fulaingt go huafásach dá bharr; 2 mhilliún duine ídithe as a mbailte, 1.6 milliún duine tar éis teitheadh trasna na teorann agus 7.5 milliún duine i mbaol ocrais. Meastar go mbeidh ar a laghad EUR 1.4 billiún ag teastáil chun cuidiú leis na bochtáin agus, chun creidiúint a thabhairt don Aontas, táimid ag tabhairt EUR 381 mhilliún. Ach i ndeireadh na dála, níl ach freagra amháin ann: deireadh a chur leis an gcogadh cathartha uafásach seo.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: for the S&D group.- Mr President!Thank you to all the political groups for the broad coherence that has been shown with this resolution.First a snapshot: I saw my son, my little baby with chubby cheeks, rumbling on the floor at home, and at the same time you get reports from TV news with children with big eyes, dull eyes, small body.Then a debate on food waste in Europe, about 90 million tonnes in food waste.And the realization that people are fleeing from famine, conflict, sexual violence;3.6 million people on the run.Nearly two million of them are children.The hunger for power of a few leads to the desperation, flight and grief of many - the people, the people, the children.These conflicts must end - human rights violations cannot be allowed to continue.Thank you for this resolution, but let this be the start of work within the EU.Not least the Commission and the Member States must act.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is just five months since our last resolution concerning South Sudan, and the situation there has actually worsened. The country is verging on becoming a failed state. Famine was declared in parts of the country in February, in part due to the chaotic political and economic situation; increasingly, voices are being raised with concerns that the conflict is escalating towards genocide; and such grave war-crime concerns must now be taken extremely seriously and all options considered. Not only is there a humanitarian obligation to act but the impact of further escalation, in an already destabilising region of the Horn of Africa, would be detrimental to EU Member State interests. Nearly a year after the UN Security Council voted to send a regional military protection force of 4 000 troops to supplement the existing UNMISS peacekeeping forces, I am pleased to note at last that the South Sudanese authorities have finally, and for the first time, allowed these troops to arrive and be stationed on their territory. This is a welcome step but the EU must now go on to pressure South Sudan fully to honour all its obligations and to bring all the war criminals to justice.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. President, last Tuesday, in this Chamber, the President of the Commission of the African Union called on us: "to strengthen the Africa-Europe partnership and to build bridges". I fear that the bloodthirsty regime in Juba has chosen isolation. The figures are tragic: tens of thousands of deaths since the start of the civil war three years ago, more than 3 million displaced inhabitants, rape as a weapon of war, child soldiers and then this famine, which leaves one million severely malnourished people, including 600,000 children. And yet, because hope is a risk to be taken - as Bernanos writes - the European Union must play its part in the search for a way out. In this regard, I welcome the very recent opening by Sudan of humanitarian corridors and the role of mediator that the Democratic Republic of the Congo wishes to take in establishing a dialogue of reconciliation. The United Nations also obviously has a leading role to play; the deployment of a regional force under UN command to ensure security, which would reinforce the contingent of 13,000 peacekeepers already there, now sounds obvious.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, I remember a meeting on Sudan where there was our President’s Special Advisor, the Ambassador and the Church in Need. We were against the partition of Sudan because we imagined the consequences of this partition. The international community, namely the West, supported this partition for energy and economic reasons. Since then, interethnic oppositions have taken their rights with the benevolent support of regional powers, like Uganda, and Western countries, which have already sponsored secession, like the United States, causing civil war. Sudan is a textbook case of what the West is doing to Africa. Moreover, this is what we also see in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. We played on ethnic partitions to obtain territorial partitions and to serve our interests behind it all. The only possible way is to let African communities redesign their way of organizing into viable and sovereign states.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, political conflict and famine have created an unprecedented humanitarian crisis in South Sudan. More than five million people in the country need help, millions of people are facing hunger, more than 3.6 million people are displaced, including one million children. The conflict in Sudan should worry us all. It is vital for the European Union to ensure that the parties to the conflict want to commit to a ceasefire agreement. The flow of weapons continues to encourage conflict. The European Union must impose an arms embargo. Reports that several countries, including Ukraine and Israel, continue to transfer weapons to South Sudan, facilitated by brokers in the Member States, are a matter of deep concern. In January 2016, UN investigators found that in addition to hundreds of light and heavy machine guns, a private Ukrainian company called Motors Sich had sold an attack helicopter worth $ 42 million in southern Sudan under a contract authorized by the authority. export of the Ukrainian state. Let's not forget that this was in 2014, after Ukraine signed the arms embargo with the European Union. In addition, it is suspected that Ukrainian mercenaries are in the country to ensure that these helicopters work. Control is needed.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen,When South Sudan was founded six years ago, we looked at with the hope that the Christian communities living in the south would be able to break free from the control of a failed state that was Sudan as a whole.However, Honorable Members, civil wars do happen in newly emerged states.They are predictable, it was possible to predict it.It has also happened in Europe.We took little responsibility for this country, which in its geopolitical environment needed our help, and today the remarks made in this Chamber by my colleagues - Charles Tannock, Javier Nart - are very accurate.Sudan needs greater solidarity from the West, because the world does not need a new Euro-civilization at all, but responsibility on the part of Europe and the values of European civilization.It needs proven values and our specific commitment, not general guidance.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, yesterday we had the UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, who warned of the growing number of world conflicts that currently affect thousands of people around the world and who, in close cooperation between the UN and the Union European Union, it is urgent to resolve. And precisely one of the conflicts that was remembered here was the one that has endured, for three years, in South Sudan and that has turned into a real civil war of Dantesque dimensions, where the Government is one of the main responsible for the violation of human rights, through large-scale military operations. Dear colleagues, without questioning the goodwill of the UN, the truth is that, in 2016, the United Nations Security Council, which could have intervened to impose on the Sudanese Government an immediate end to all military operations, did not want to adopt a resolution that would have imposed an arms embargo on South Sudan. I therefore believe that, regardless of the UN's readiness or inertia, the European Union must act now and increase humanitarian aid to South Sudan, while imposing a total embargo on arms sales to South Sudan, with strict compliance with EU arms export control to that country. That is our obligation as Europeans.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - The situation in South Sudan is a real challenge for the EU.The people of South Sudan are more concerned with survival, although the exercise of fundamental human rights must not be overlooked.The numbers vary, but they are millions and most of them are children.These people are seeking refuge in 6 neighboring countries, where we are witnessing the fastest growing refugee crisis in the world.According to UNHCR, $ 1.4 billion needs to be provided to provide basic assistance to these refugees by the end of 2017.The EU must therefore use its influence to try to reach a political solution to the conflict in South Sudan in the field of international diplomacy and to provide support to neighboring countries so that the situation in the region does not deteriorate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the desperate situation in Sudan is described in the resolution, which I have also signed and supported. The civil war is raging right now. We have thousands of refugees, I would say millions, who are trying to be saved. Most of them are children. The rest of the population is facing a huge problem of hunger. What worries me most is that children are being recruited into groups that are in conflict, which, of course, proves to be a war crime. We have constant rape of women and girls, we have the annihilation of Christian communities, and of course all this is part of the conflict of the various races, but also of those who incite these conflicts, in order to seize the wealth that exists in this country. Therefore, there must be immediate European Union intervention, both financially and, above all, under an arms embargo on the region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the civil war that began in 2013 in South Sudan is now largely degenerating towards a probable genocide. Ethnic killings and ethnic rhetoric talk of political leaders are now commonplace, sexual assault, rape, gang rape, abduction of women and girls and sexual slavery are techniques widely used as weapons of war. The now daily clashes between the opposition and the government on the ground are leading to a flow of over 100 000 people, last week alone, 42 per cent of the population lives in conditions of insecurity and more than 7 million people are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance, while impunity is rampant. We condemn in this resolution the current state of the situation and strongly call for a ceasefire, for the European Union and all its member states to make a strong commitment to stop the massacres by both sides, to reopen the humanitarian corridors and achieving true peaceful cooperation. At this moment, it is also essential that the interposition forces have a central role because such violence could actually degenerate into genocide, for which we could also be responsible for our inaction.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I will start with a personal remark because, during the last parliamentary term, I discussed the situation in South Sudan on many occasions with a number of you from the Committee on Development and the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Now, on behalf of Vice-President / High Representative Mogherini, I would like to tell you how sorry I am to see that, after our many years of discussing this same issue here, the situation is getting worse instead of improving. The situation is on the verge of catastrophe. The country is consumed by anarchy and disorder, with atrocious acts of violence commonplace. Civilians are being deliberately and systematically attacked, often with an ethnic intent, by a range of armed opposition groups, and notably in large offensives by the Sudan People’s Liberation Army. A hundred people are dying each month and some 1.8 million refugees have fled to neighbouring countries, while almost 2 million persons are internally displaced. Famine has been declared in parts of the country. The European Union is doing everything possible to encourage peace. It undertakes ongoing political dialogue with the transitional government to urge implementation of the 2015 Peace Agreement. We are fully engaged with regional efforts, through the African Union and the Intergovernmental Authority on Development, to end the conflict. The European Union has provided almost EUR 0.5 billion in humanitarian assistance to South Sudan since the conflict started in December 2013. Our support to the region has been increased to address a massive influx of refugees. The European Union has imposed an arms embargo against South Sudan and is lobbying for the UN Security Council to follow it. The European Union is appalled at the gross violation of human rights and international humanitarian law perpetrated by all parties with complete impunity. It has encouraged the African Union to establish a ‘hybrid court’ for South Sudan, as envisaged in the Peace Agreement, as soon as possible. Let me reiterate today our messages to all parties. There can be no military solution. All parties must observe the ceasefire in full. The United Nations peacekeeping mission in South Sudan must be allowed to exercise its mandate without restriction, so all parties must allow unfettered humanitarian access to those in need, and attacks on aid workers must stop. The national dialogue launched by President Kiir must be transformed into an inclusive political process, truly open to all parties, which is deemed credible by the South Sudanese people. People’s lives – mainly the lives of South Sudanese people – hang in the balance, threatened by violence, famine and destitution. The European Union will continue to deploy all instruments available – political pressure, sanctions, development assistance, international justice – with a view to encouraging the parties to replace conflict with dialogue. Thank you for your attention. I look forward to good news.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - A bloody civil war is underway in South Sudan, which began in 2013. The war has brought the economy and society of this already very poor African country to its knees. For a long time human rights have not been respected and the population is forced to suffer all kinds of violence and abuse. Murders, rapes and kidnappings, unfortunately, are the sad everyday life. As if that weren't enough, this humanitarian crisis is exacerbated by a terrible famine, which the UN estimates is putting the lives of millions of people in South Sudan at risk. Faced with this desperate picture that South Sudan is today, decisive, immediate and joint action by the European Union with other international actors is needed to save this African country. War and violence must be stopped as soon as possible. Humanitarian corridors are needed as soon as possible to alleviate the atrocious suffering of the population. We must make our voices heard so that what is happening in South Sudan does not pass over in silence!

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, despite the fact that we are in a hurry, I think this is an opportunity to remind ourselves of the fate of a small nation, the Crimean Tatars, who were deported as an ethnic group 73 years ago, on 18 May 1944. Yesterday a Ukrainian delegation was here and they reminded us that the famous ‘never again’ does not apply, until now, to Crimean Tatars. They are under Russian occupation now and several of them have no access to their homeland. So I call on us to remember this and express our solidarity with this nation.  (Applause)

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Madam President, Ukraine has banned MEPs and me from entering the country because of my visit to Dobas in 2014, as well as banning political parties and outlawing the Communist Party of Ukraine. The Ukrainian presidency said in a statement yesterday that Poroshenko, in yesterday's meeting with the President of the European Parliament, called on the MEPs to respond and take measures to prevent MEPs from visiting Dobas and Crimea. This is not a personal matter, but a serious political one. It concerns MEPs and the European Parliament. Both the entry ban and Poroshenko's unacceptable request for the Bureau to check where MEPs are allowed to go and where not should be immediately condemned. Is the next step to check what they will say?

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: This was not really a point of order, but I accepted it because there was also another statement before and so I accepted both of those. But we are not having a debate on any of these things. This is just about a point of order.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I only agree with what has just been said, in ten seconds I want to say that yesterday not only Poroshenko was here, but also the Ukrainian Foreign Minister, to whom I was able to read his and his statements.his spokesman, who spoke of a request for arrest and indictment for terrorism.I believe it is very serious that these words can be said to the detriment of a European parliamentarian ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Ms Forenza, we are not having a debate. I am sorry, I will have to cut you off. We are not having a debate on what happened yesterday in this Parliament. This is on points of order, nothing else.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item is the vote.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, my Group wishes to move an oral amendment which has been lodged, I am afraid, very late, so it does not appear on the voting lists. On paragraph one, this is a technical-factual update to the text, asking to incorporate the following: ‘and to drop the cases against Berhanu Nega and Jawar Mohammed, who were charged in absentia and are currently in exile;’.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, again it is a factual update. I wish to add the following: ‘whereas online activist Yonatan Tesfaye has been convicted under anti-terrorism legislation for comments he made on Facebook, and faces between 10 to 20 years in prison;’.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: - Mr President, pursuant to Rule 59a of the Rules of Procedure, I request that this report be referred back to committee.I spoke to the legal services today: this report, which we are now voting on, is not the same as what we voted on in the Committee on Culture.The report has changed radically since then.The fact that the Legal Service has since amended the text has been used in part as justification.I do not blame the rapporteurs for this, but when the Legal Service says that the text is no longer the same, I think it would be reasonable to take into account the suggestions made by Members and return the text to committee and take it forward over time.It cannot be the case that the text is approved by the committee and then radically changed and voted on here in the Chamber.This is also a question of legal protection for MEPs.There has to be good legislation and there is no rush to run.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Takkula, you cannot use Rule 59 on this. You have to use Rule 190. If you want to do that you have to tell us, and then you need the support of a Group, your Group or another one, or you need 38 MEPs who support it. So my first question to you is: do you want to use Rule 190?

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: - Mr President, although then Article 190.The point is that if you get information this morning that the text is radically different from what has been adopted, I do not know whether the articles will help here.I think this House should then consider the legislation to be appropriate.190 then.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Takkula, Rule 193 says texts adopted by Parliament shall be subject to legal-linguistic finalisation under the responsibility of the President. As far as I understand, this has been done on this text. Legal linguistic changes are fine and should be done with every text so they fit what it is supposed to mean. So if you are not asking for Rule 190, I cannot follow up on a vote or whether you have enough support on a vote about referral back to committee, so either you ask for Rule 190 or I have to continue with the vote. Please decide what you want.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: - Mr President, I concluded this in recent speeches, but perhaps it was not made clear through interpretation.Please politely apply Article 190.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Now I understand you well – you want to apply Rule 190. Do you have the support of your Group? Just a second, let me go one step after the other. Do you have the support of your Group? It does not look like it. Or the support of 38 MEPs? Will those who support the request please stand up? Is it the ALDE Group? All right. We have a Group supporting the request for Rule 190 on adjournment of the vote and referral back to committee. We will now have one MEP speaking in favour and one speaking against. I will first give the floor for one minute to an MEP speaking in favour of Rule 190 and referral back to committee. Mr Dzhambazki, you have the floor.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, on behalf of the ECR, ALDE, EFDD and GUE groups, who rarely find common ground and unite around the idea, based on the principles of full transparency, democratic legitimacy, we say as elected representatives in this House that we want to prevent the damage that this harmful report in its current form would bring when it becomes legislation. It was voted by less than 3 percent of MEPs. The report of the Committee on Culture and Education fails to address both elements, while fragmenting, instead of promoting, the European Union's digital single market. The report fails to achieve its goals when it comes to ensuring a level playing field for new and old market participants. Last but not least, it significantly extends the scope of this directive, the reference content it is intended to regulate, to online communities where people share information, ideas, personal messages ... (the speaker is interrupted by the President)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Dzhambazki, can you come to the end please? It was one minute but the time was set late.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - ..the other groups, as you obviously do not want to hear the whole justification, on behalf of ECR, ALDE, EFDD and GUE, please vote against the mandate!

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Dzhambazki, there are certain rules on how we proceed in situations like this, that is why I asked you to keep to one minute. The clock was set a bit late so thank you for finishing your remark. Who is going to speak against the proposal for referral back to committee? Ms Verheyen, you have the floor also for one minute.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! The colleague Hannu Takkula raises a point in a recital which has not been changed in the article. In consideration of this, we cannot make contradicting statements to the article. In this respect, the Legal Service has consequently removed a certain part from the recital that is not so reflected in the article. In the current guideline, the advertisement for betting and games is already included. We have removed the games themselves, i.e. betting and gambling, from the scope of the directive. It stays that way. Whereas Mr Takkula wanted to include the advertisement in it but not in the article and so the Legal Service removed that. That is the point of contention that Mr Takkula raised at the moment. I tried to explain to him this morning. The fact is that the legal service actually only did what the legal service was supposed to do: correct everything that is legally not okay. In this respect, I am speaking against this proposal. In principle, the committee accepted the mandate for the trialogue with a two-thirds majority. If we are of the opinion here now that the committee cannot speak for Parliament, then we have to vote differently accordingly.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: We have heard the arguments. What we are going to vote on now is just whether we postpone the vote or whether we vote on it now. Let me put it differently. The question is: are we going to postpone the vote? Is that clear to everybody? Postponement of the vote. Who is in favour of postponement? Who is against? This is a majority. It was very clear, but I will check so that we do not have any concerns here. (The request to postpone the vote was rejected)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I wonder what the case is for these countries to be making payments to less developed parts of the EU. I do not think we can make a moral case for it: there are many more deserving parts of our planet than EU Member States. If you have extra money to give away you should surely be giving it to the places where it will be most put to use. It is bizarre that we are giving more to wealthy European farmers than to poor African farmers. Perhaps the case is supposed to be economic, but if it is then I submit it is not working terribly well. If grants from the EU raised a country’s economic standard, then Greece would be the wealthiest country in Europe, having been the biggest per capita recipient of funds since 1981. There would be arguments in this House about whether the Greeks should continue to bail out the Germans. In fact, the best way for us to raise the standards of living of any country is simply to allow them to engage in global markets, and that means looking beyond Europe and raising our eyes to more distant horizons.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, EU cohesion policy mainly consist of a mix of grants and financial instruments. Some Latvian officials support the replacement of grants with loans in the future. The arguments are that it is more difficult to receive grants than loans, because you have to persuade the bank to give you the loan to realise the project for this money, check the proper realisation of the project and only after that do you receive the grant. This algorithm makes it difficult for businesses. Sometimes projects do not, at the beginning, have a profitable future but receiving the grant is a final aim of the project. On the other side, grants have a lot of positive features, each of these instruments have their strengths and weaknesses, both grants and financial instruments have their specific roles in cohesion policy. Financial instruments perform better in well-developed regions and metropolitan areas while grants address regional structural issues in outermost regions and regions with a high unemployment rate. I voted in favour.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Technical assistance regarding cohesion funds is one of the most important tools for these funds to achieve their goal.It is true, however, that there are far too few routes open at the so-called local and regional level, which can significantly reduce the possibility of drawing on European funds.However, as we have already heard today, cohesion funds are essential for the more even and fairer development of the European Union.Therefore, in the future it is necessary to pay more attention to the cutting of cohesion funds for a more balanced development potential of European countries.And it is precisely this technical aspect and technical assistance that can strengthen both the administrative part and the capacity on the one hand, as well as, of course, the ability to draw at all levels.And it is here that it seems to me that there is still a lot of idleness in terms of integration at the national, regional and local levels, so of course it is necessary to support all efforts that go in this direction.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, cohesion policy plays a very important role in achieving the policies set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Article 174 of it requires the development and implementation of initiatives that lead to the strengthening of economic, social and territorial cohesion. In this regard, the role of cohesion funds is key. However, local, regional and national authorities often do not have the necessary capacity to implement the European Structural and Investment Funds effectively and efficiently and to organize partnerships with other public authorities, such as local authorities, economic and social partners and civil society. Following the entry into force of technical assistance in the field of cohesion policy, no general analysis has been carried out to establish its real contribution. Well-used technical measures are a prerequisite for attracting industrial investment in high-tech and innovative sectors with low environmental impact.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I supported this proposal, which aims to establish a binding obligation for all Member States to harmonize consumers' access to online services to which they have paid for access in their home country.Portability should therefore be an undeniable right of the consumer, without prejudice to the principle of territoriality.This legislation will be able to be put into practice if the associated terms are clearly defined, such as the Member State, the consumer's residence, temporary presence in another state.I think that this temporary presence should not be limited to a specific number of days or weeks, because this restriction actually limits the purpose of this regulation.Thus, to give all consumers the opportunity to travel around the EU while maintaining legally acquired access to online content services.So this is my position and thank you for approving the report.

name: Momchil NEKOV
