text: - Madam President, the free movement of people, goods, capital and services is a fundamental element of the European single market. In order for it to be fully functional, we need to add free data movement. It seems paradoxical that European citizens can move freely within the European Union, but this is not the case with the services they buy, which cannot move with them. Today, each of us uses a smartphone, laptop or tablet in our daily lives with the presumption that the Internet has no boundaries. This, however, is only apparent. For example, if a Bulgarian consumer has purchased a subscription for online TV services where he can watch his favorite Bulgarian series, then access to them will be automatically restricted the moment he decides to leave the territory of Bulgaria. I take the position that this injustice must end, and that is why I supported the proposal for a regulation. I believe that Bulgarian and European citizens have the right to listen to their favorite music and watch their favorite movies while traveling outside their homeland.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I supported this own-initiative report on the implementation of the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement.The current balance confirms that the trade agreement is very mutually beneficial.In terms of goods, South Korea is the 9th largest export destination for EU member states, while the EU is South Korea's 3rd largest export market.That is why I welcome the fact that almost all tariff barriers between the EU and South Korea have been successfully removed.The agreement, increased exports to the EU and Korean investment have created 100,000 new jobs in the EU.However, the report also draws attention to the emergence of protectionist measures on the Korean side introducing non-tariff barriers.These are, for example, new technical standards for machines imported from the EU and need to be overseen by the Commission.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, while there are a number of very positive suggestions in this resolution on the EU-Korea free-trade deal, I still abstained because of the proposals on setting up the special investor courts to replace the old ones. The new system would involve the setting up of special courts, outside the jurisdiction of national courts or the European Court of Justice, where investors could sue governments if they believe that the actions taken or the legislation adopted by those governments would put their investments at risk. Examples of this are where tobacco companies have successfully sued the Uruguay Government over public health legislation or where American waste companies successfully sued the Canadian Government when it tried to ban the export of toxic poly-chlorinated biphenyl (PCB) waste. I strongly argue that we do not need special courts to protect investors. We do not have special courts to protect citizens’ rights, to protect the environment, or to protect human rights or workers’ rights. This week, the Commission launched a communication on harnessing globalisation and making it work for citizens. Giving the same level of protection to citizens, to workers and to investors would be a great start.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – As we approach the fifth anniversary of the entry into force of the free-trade agreement (FTA) between the European Union and the Republic of Korea, I find it most timely that we should review its implementation. I therefore welcome this report’s assessment of an agreement that went so much further than previous FTAs in lifting trade barriers with our Asian partners. Notably, the agreement has led to a 47% increase in EU exports to Korea, transforming a EUR 7.6 billion deficit into a EUR 2.5 billion European Union trade surplus and creating 200 000 jobs. Looking to the future, we should therefore aim to strengthen this trading relationship further, a relationship that we may harness to encourage further economic growth and development for the mutual benefit of the EU and Korean citizens: a ‘win win’!

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, after all, this resolution, despite its positive points, represents a step backwards in relation to positions taken previously by the European Parliament in support of the two states' solution. I am concerned that it will put occupant and occupied on an equal footing, not even hurting the occupation and failing to ask Member States to strictly comply with the principle of differentiation, Security Council resolution 2334; that it does not condemn the racist nationality law that Israel has just adopted, making Israeli Arabs second-class citizens; that the mention of the EU-Israel trade agreement is ambiguous, not clarifying that it is necessary to ensure that products produced in Palestine, or that are based on the illegal exploitation of Palestinian resources, cannot be marketed in Europe under an Israeli label; to make a biased attack, in line with the government of the Israeli extreme right, on the French initiative that the European Parliament supported, as did the Commission, the High Representative and the Council; that condemns only acts of violence and terrorist attacks against Israelis. So what about Palestinians? In short, this resolution fails to send a consistent message to the Government of Israel and the Palestinian authorities of European determination in support of the two states' solution and a just and lasting peace solution for the two peoples in conflict.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, it is positive that the EU has made an attempt to adopt and implement a new strategy to resolve the Syrian crisis. Frankly speaking, Europeans had begun to lose faith in the European Union as a serious participant in the settlement of the Syrian conflict. According to recent opinion polls in Latvia, only 10% of the Latvian population think that EU action to resolve the Syrian conflict is effective. High Representative Federica Mogherini’s speech two days ago, in this House, gave me hope that the EU position had become more realistic and more effective. Diplomacy cannot be based on the allegation that virtually all parties to the conflict, except us, are criminals and we will not speak with them! This is not diplomacy, this is stupidity. Such a position leads to isolation and offers no hope to the Syrian people. I support Federica Mogherini’s assertion that the main EU instruments are humanitarian aid and money for reconstruction, negotiation, cooperation and diplomacy.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that, in the face of the unprecedented humanitarian disaster in our recent history, that European country must continue to make all political and diplomatic efforts to combat the use of weapons chemicals, to create a more humane, humane and secure European migration policy and to find a peaceful solution to the Syrian conflict, including accompanying instruments to reinforce respect for the commitments made within the international group that supports Syria. The European Union, being the largest donor of funds, reinforces with this resolution its commitment to contribute, in a more visible and effective way, to alleviate the humanitarian consequences of the conflict and to appeal again to the need for accountability to the authors of the unspeakable atrocities committed by the regime and its allies, a necessary condition for lasting peace in that martyred country. As the United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres, said yesterday in his brilliant speech in this House, the Syrian conflict is a terrible threat to global security, where no one wins and everyone loses.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Let me explain why I did not ultimately support the resolution on road transport. This resolution contains a number of stimulating proposals, including an emphasis on new technologies and economic models. Self-driving cars, carsharing They are the future of road transport and the European Commission must set the right regulatory framework for their development. In the end, however, I did not support the resolution and I will explain why. Because I reject some of the proposals and pressure from the old Member States to apply my wage policy to drivers from other Member States, beyond the minimum standards. These steps threaten the free movement of services and goods across the European market. In addition, further regulation of working and other conditions prevents SMEs from accessing the market, which is in direct conflict with the objectives declared in some points. Last but not least, I doubt the usefulness of this resolution shortly before the Commission presents a comprehensive road transport package.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - I voted against this report because it contradicts fundamental freedoms in the European Union, because it is lobbying, because it imposes unacceptable protectionism and because it is against the interests of the citizens of Eastern Europe. And why is it against them? At least 100,000 people in my homeland, Bulgaria, make a living from the transport business. Probably millions of others in the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, Romania, make a living from this business. They have given a price for the service, won these orders and are driving throughout the European Union. Companies in Germany, Belgium and France are envious of these prices and have decided to "protect" the rights of workers in Eastern Europe by taking their jobs. This is absolutely wrong. This will not work. Inadmissible restrictions are introduced on the right to free movement, on entrepreneurship, drivers are urged to leave their trucks and go to sleep 10, 15, 20 kilometers by taxi. This will not happen. This report runs counter to freedom of movement in the European Union. This report is against the interests of Eastern European entrepreneurs. And that's why I voted against it, and that's why I say it's harmful.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, in the next few weeks, the Commission will unveil its new proposals for regulation of road transport. Improving workers’ rights in this sector and stopping the exploitation of truck, bus and coach drivers should be the absolute top priority of these proposals.  Unfortunately, this resolution does not sufficiently underline this priority and in particular the paragraph on establishing a European road transport agency to protect and promote workers’ rights, amongst other areas, including proper enforcement of road transport legislation, was rejected. This resolution also does not establish sufficiently strong protections on tackling climate change and air pollution. So in overall terms, I am sorry to say that I voted against this resolution.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: - Madam President! We in the European Parliament today adopted an important resolution on Somali refugees. There are 260,000 people in the Dadaab camp in Kenya. The European Parliament notes that there is a European recognition of our responsibility to contribute to better conditions in the camp specifically and to Somalis in general, because it is not an option for Kenya to send people back to Somalia due to the conditions in the country. All the more blatant is the fact that some of our own governments are actively deporting men, women and children, even children born in EU Member States, to Somalia. Kenya obviously must not, we must do well! A country like Ethiopia does not, we do! It is unsustainable, and therefore it is extremely important that we were given a general admonition in paragraph 7, which states that due to the serious situation, any return to Somalia should be exclusively and always voluntary. It should go without saying that there is no deportation to perhaps the world's most dangerous country. I strongly urge human rights advocates to use this decision in any cases they may bring before the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, we are concentrating too much on the issue that not all Member States have fulfilled their commitments with regard to the relocation of 160 000 refugees, and we are failing to pay attention to what happens with these people after relocation. According to the Integration Foundation in Latvia, from April 2016 to April 2017, 308 refugees out of 487 left Latvia. Latvia has rather good results on relocation, our Government does not loudly oppose relocation, as Hungary, Poland and Slovakia do, but Latvian legislators have adopted a very small and poor social package for refugees and have imposed severe language restrictions that do not allow these people to work, even casually. Colleagues, I see no practical necessity for formal relocation if the people concerned will not live in this country.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that, in view of the Commission's latest report on regulation and resettlement and in the absence of a much-needed European asylum system based on shared responsibility, Member States have to honor the obligations assumed before asylum seekers from Greece and Italy and, if they do not, must be subject to the opening of infringement procedures. As I said, Madam President, so far only 17 903 asylum seekers have been relocated. What justification can we give to the more than 142 000 people, many of them minors, unaccompanied, who, in unworthy conditions and in a vulnerable system, wait for the Member States to fulfill their commitments? Dear colleagues, the refugee crisis is also the result of the crisis of European solidarity. For this reason, I understand that it is our duty to do everything so that, in Europe, refugees are properly accompanied and protected.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: - That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the major interpellation (Rule 130b) by Dubravka Šuica, Franc Bogovič, Daniel Buda, Pál Csáky, Andor Deli, György Hölvényi, Marijana Petir, Ivan Štefanec, Patricija Šulin, AlojzPeterle, Marian-Jean Marinescu, Miroslav Mikolášik, Ivana Maletić, Milan Zver, Tomáš Zdechovský, Inese Vaidere, Traian Ungureanu, Željana Zovko, Eduard Kukan, Krišjānis Kariņš, Ivica Tolić, Romana Tomc, Dariusz Rosati, Artis Pabriks, Adam RenatejSommer, Pavel Svoboda, Michaela Šojdrova, Iuliu Winkler, Zigmantas Balčytis, Nicola Caputo, Doru-Claudian Frunzulică, Georgi Pirinski, Monika Smolkova, Olga Sehnalová, Biljana Borzan, Tonino Picula, Anna Elżbieta Fotyga, Jana Makcovešić, Ruža TomašićGeorgios Epitideios, Ivan Jakovčić, Ivo Vajgl, Merja Kyllönen and Julia Pitera (O-000019/17 - B8-0220 / 2017) (2017/2676 (RSP)).

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: author. - Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I greet you and at the beginning I would like to express my joy that this item has come on the agenda. I would like to thank my colleagues who supported this proposal with 43 signatures, and I take this opportunity to thank you that the interpellation saw the light of day in this plenary session. I am also pleased that, as of today, my fellow Members from the countries most affected by this issue are present here. In any case, what we want to point out is the obvious difference in product quality between the Western European market and the Central European and Eastern market. Studies have already been completed in many countries and this has been proven. In some countries these studies are still being done, but in any case there is an obvious difference and we want to point to the single European market and we believe that all consumers must have equal rights, strive for cohesion, strive for equality and that is why we have raised this interpellation to daily order. We would like our children to enjoy the same standards in that common Europe that we have all worked so hard for together. My two questions to the Commission expressed in this interpellation are: Given the single market, what measures does the Commission intend to take to eliminate single market sharing practices? And the second question: Will the Commission revise European Union legislation to protect consumers by removing double standards in the quality of products sold in Central, Eastern and Western Europe? The deadline for response was April 12. We didn't get it. That is one of the reasons why this item came up on the agenda. We have also requested the initiation, that is, the initiation of a change in legislation related to this issue, so I expect, after the discussion this afternoon, that Ms. Crețu may also respond that the Commission intends to continue with this issue. Once again, thank you to all colleagues who participated in this and to a colleague from Croatia who started a study on this issue so that we proved that there really are differences.This has already been proven in Slovakia, it has been proven in the Czech Republic, Hungary.Our agriculture ministers also supported this issue at the Council meeting, and I believe that you, as the Commission, will answer this.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, dear rapporteur, I am glad to speak on behalf of Commissioner Věra Jourová, my colleague, on this very important and so sensitive issue, as you rightly raised. It is very important to discuss it. Existing EU legislation aims to ensure a high level of consumer protection, safety, and correct and reliable consumer information. We think that only safe food products are allowed on the EU market – as we said, we have a single market – and of course, consumers must be accurately informed and not misled about the composition and characteristics of food offered for sale. We have general labelling rules and requirements to that effect, and it is EU legislation which ensures that producers have to make a complete list of ingredients that enables the consumers to be fully informed of the composition of the food product. This being said, as long as products comply with EU legal requirements and their labelling does not mislead consumers as to the main characteristics, companies are not prevented from differentiating products according to the market. There is no legal basis, unfortunately, at EU level to challenge differences in food composition in individual Member States, as long as the relevant food information is not misleading. However, should a trader advertise a product as being the same in several Member States, but at the same time deliberately reduce the quality of the product in some of these countries compared to others, this practice could be addressed under the Directive on unfair commercial practices by the competent national authority. EU consumer law allows national enforcement authorities or courts to end specific misleading commercial practices if they consider that they are harming consumers. After the investigations and many events coming from this House, the Commission has called on Member States to provide further data and evidence in order to assess the existence and extent of these alleged practices and possible reasons for them. So far, the Commission has received 21 replies from the Member States. According to the received replies, the issue of dual quality is considered a big problem, especially in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia and Croatia. The main products concern food, laundry detergents and pet food. The investigations carried out in several countries showed said the labelling of these products corresponds to their composition. In other Member States there is no particular data or evidence related to the issue of dual quality so far. In order to tackle this important issue, more cooperation among enforcement agencies is needed, so as to elaborate an objective mapping and to compare products sold in several Member States. The Commission intends to provide the results of this mapping for the next SHERPA meeting of the high-level forum for a better functioning of the food supply chain on 20 June, in line with a conclusion of the European Council of 9 March 2017. This forum will enable, for the first time, an exchange of views between all concerned actors, such as consumer representatives, industry at various stages of the supply chain, Member States’ authorities and the Commission. Some of you have called on the Commission to propose a specific legislation to prohibit dual quality. In our view, the reinforcement of existing laws should be strengthened in the first place. I trust that the on-going debate on the process of collecting evidence will raise the awareness of all concerned players on the issue and help address it to the benefit of all European citizens and consumers. On our part, we will build on the results of the consultation of national authorities and the outcome of debate in the high-level forum. I am looking forward for our debate.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Thank you very much, but without the trust of consumers in entrepreneurs, the common market has no chance of functioning well, and the very fact that some markets - in this case Central European - are targeted at lower quality products, lowers this trust. I do not criticize entrepreneurs for directing different offers to different markets, because they have the right to do so, but it is unacceptable that there are fundamental differences in quality, and they are, and that consumers are misled. If it is true that a certain company's biscuits sold in Poland contain 5% butter and some palm oil, and the same biscuits in the same packaging in Germany contain 12% butter and no palm oil, this is simply a scandal. Maybe something petitem is written there, I don't know. We often talk about washing powders that have the same packaging, foam and smell different, so we proposed a pilot project requesting an assessment of the alleged quality differences in products sold in the common market. Commissioner! I am asking the Commission to support this project. Together we will change these bad practices.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, several Member States face a number of worrying assumptions, both among consumers and among producers, regarding the quality of products imported into the country, compared to the same products in other European countries. Of course, we cannot compare a product with another product unless it has the same supplier, if it has the same quality, if it is labeled that way. In a word, we can only tell the difference if the products have the same origin and distribution in the Member States, and in all this we must also take into account the fact that current legislation allows branded products to be adapted to the market on which they are sold. a common practice for several reasons: adaptation to consumer tastes, local customs and access to raw materials. In this context, Commissioner, I believe that a solution must be found at European level so that, on the basis of objective differences in quality and the communication of those brands, it can be determined to what extent producers mislead consumers when it comes to the quality of imported products. national territory, compared to the same products existing in other European countries.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! The topic of our discussion today only seems trivial, because in fact it concerns a huge number of European Union citizens - both in my country, in Poland, but also in many other new Member States - who are clearly discriminated against by producers of food or cleaning products. We are now sure that the common opinion about the lower quality of products offered on the markets of Central and Eastern European countries is based on many studies and analyzes. Consumers in my country have had similar concerns about the quality of food, toiletries, cleaning products and disinfectants for many years. However, the most outrageous in this case is the policy of many large concerns. Firstly, they mislead consumers by not providing reliable information about the different composition of the same products in the west and east of Europe, differences which, for example in relation to food, may even have a negative impact on public health. Secondly, the prices of lower quality products available, among others, in Poland are in many cases higher than the prices of their counterparts in the West. The treatment of consumers in my region of Europe as second-class customers undoubtedly deserves a reaction at the European level. Nobody expects complete unification of the composition of all products across Europe, but we cannot accept such far-reaching differences between the composition and quality of the same goods offered on the common market but in different Member States. Given that the problem is of a European nature, the Commission should not only take a position on this outrageous matter, but also use all available tools and means to investigate the problem and take the appropriate response to protect consumers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club.- Mr. President, I must say that I am very glad that you are here, Madam Commissioner, because I believe that you are very sensitive to the topic we are talking about.Of course, I would like to thank my colleagues at the very beginning who have been launching this topic for months, which is extremely, extremely current.And it is problematic for one simple reason.It calls into question our entire credibility.The credibility of the whole system we have created in the European Union, the agencies we have created in the European Union, everything that means control and monitoring within the European Union.We cannot have first and second order citizens.Well ladies and gentlemen, we have first and second order pets looks in the European Union.I think that is definitely unbelievable.That is why I call on the Commission to think carefully and to start drafting new regulations as soon as possible.(The speaker agreed to answer the question by raising a blue card pursuant to Rule 162 (8)).

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Question asked by raising a blue card.- I agree with your thesis about the duality of quality, which can also affect health and, of course, quality of life.Do you think that it would make sense to consider leaving it as an independent body at European level, where we have the so-called European Consumers' Union, to do a European research on these problems and, in fact, to propose appropriate measures and appropriate measures?administrative frameworks and, above all, sanctions that can prevent this misleading?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- I completely agree with you, Mr. Šoltes, and I must say that such a neutral research is partly done by Ms. Borzan at the moment and financed from its own funds, but just a little while ago it was suggested by Ms. von Thun und Hohenstein.I think that's exactly the way to go.Institutions need to do this research, and not just MPs who really want to do their utmost to show the correctness of our views.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, first I would like to thank my colleagues who are present. If I am here, it is because I am from Strasbourg and I want to support the holding of the session in Strasbourg as well as the work on Thursday afternoon. Moreover, the session could even extend until Friday to make Strasbourg the sole seat in parliamentary work. The question asked by the Slovak and Hungarian governments on the complaints of consumers in these countries is legitimate, but it seems to me to be poorly put. Indeed, the tests carried out by these governments do not show any infringement in respect of consumer health protection and in their information as provided for by European legislation. We are therefore not in a case of fraud or even outright deception. It is about using the prestige of a brand and its quality standards, recognized over the years in Western Europe, to sell a lower quality product, adapt the price to the standard of local life and preserve the margins of the parent company. Beyond this marketing lie, we need to think more deeply about the issue of food. Multinationals are not ideological, they pragmatically adapt their production conditions to the economy and the local market. The Commission is pursuing a globalist logic of standardization, sanitization, standardization which substitutes brands for the land, which weakens our diet and gradually causes our countries to lose their culinary identity. This policy obviously benefits the big multinationals in the food industry. The only long-term solution to this problem is to relocate production closer to consumers, to give back to our fellow citizens the tastes and flavors of their territory and to leave States the right to be more rigorous on quality standards, on appellations of origin and on the protection of their culinary identity.We must thus break with free trade, which accelerates this race for junk food by opening our markets to fruit and vegetables picked tasteless, transported thousands of kilometers in refrigerated containers.We must also put an end to the monopoly of central purchasing bodies and generalized tenders.We are faced with this situation.I myself have established large-scale distribution and I am unhappy about this policy which is being carried out, which ultimately leads to standardization and standardization and which bypasses local productions during calls foroffers because they are not competitive.Our peoples have the right to food sovereignty and to respect for their culinary identity, which are far more important issues than the brand dispute.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, a quarter of a century after the fall of the Iron Curtain, we see that all the walls between the West and the East still have not been pulled down. Even new ones have been created, and when we speak about food, we do not speak about cosmetics. We are not talking about two-speed Europe again; what we are more concerned about is already two-quality Europe. This is not acceptable: we should not allow multinational corporations to act against European values or against the spirit of our internal market. Misleading consumers’ calls for legal responsibility – but making differences between consumers within the European Union calls also for our political responsibility. I do not want Coca Cola, Nutella or Camembert West and Coca Cola, Nutella or Camembert East. Misleading consumers will last for so long, as long as they will find in their stores different products under the same brand. We need credibility of European brands, and there is no credibility without fair play. We have not been politically uniting our continent in the last decades in order to divide the citizens on the matter of quality, and surely not when food – that is, when our health – is in question.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am particularly pleased to discuss today this, for many citizens of the European Union, and very important and emotional topic. At the beginning, my colleague Olga Sehnalová and I were a bit lonely in discussions on this topic, however, I am glad that an increasing number of MPs are getting involved. I started a research in Croatia on different quality, the first of which includes, in addition to food, hygiene products. We previously conducted a survey which showed that more than 80% of citizens are convinced that products of poorer quality are placed on the eastern markets than on the western ones. Colleagues, we are in a common European market that knows no borders. We are in the European Union, which is terribly committed to the equality of all its citizens. That is why, if it turns out in all research that there is a difference in quality, it is up to us to do our best that there are no first- and second-class citizens of the European Union.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to thank my colleague Biljana Borzan and my colleague Dubravka Šuica for launching this initiative, which I supported, and I would especially like to thank all those colleagues who organized the research, parallel product comparison, which are definitely alreadyfor now, they have clearly shown that there is a difference in key foods between some products in the East and in the West, especially food and hygiene products.But this topic is not from yesterday, this topic has been going on for ten years, so this issue has existed for ten years and of course it introduces mistrust among the European Union institutions that are not able to solve this issue.It is therefore high time that this is a breach of one of the fundamental principles of the Union, which is the common market.I call on the Commission to take all measures, to remedy these shortcomings, including the necessary legislative measures.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I would like to thank the Commissioner for her comments, which, however, only confirmed the legitimacy of our concerns and our initiative. The different composition of branded products in different EU countries is difficult to legislate, as she herself stated. If the information on the packaging corresponds to the composition of the product, the product is safe, but it is difficult for an individual consumer to assess that he would buy a product in the neighboring country at the same price containing another type of sugar, more or less fat, more or less cocoa, etc. the authorities do not have the possibility to compare or even affect the difference between goods of the same brand and other compositions in other countries. I think that is why individual countries are also doing studies, which have already been mentioned here, but which clearly show a difference in composition, ie a difference in the quality of a given product. With regard to the common market, I think it is right for the Commission's activity to be greater, and I think that the proposal by my colleague from Poland for a pilot project is appropriate.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, and I would like to congratulate the initiators, but it must not be a simple question left unanswered. It is a certainty that in Eastern countries they are produced under the same brand with inferior qualities. This is a scam. I am a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and it is my duty to protect consumers, but here it is much more than the consumer. Selling a product that has inferior qualities, but bears the same brand, is a counterfeit in the end and destroys the right manufacturers. On the other hand, the consumer pays an undue price. We do not stop diversification, but the manufacturer who wants to sell for less purchasing power has only to change the name of the product, to put another brand, to put the number two to that brand, not to cheat by putting the same brand and take detergent and use three times more because the wash coefficient is lower. So, Commissioner, I think we need to intervene here with uniform, obviously European legislation, and with the national authorities. But it is clear now that those in the East are the trash, as has often been proven.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: - This is not the first time we have discussed this topic here in the EP, but unfortunately there has been no change, no correction. At the same time, even according to the latest surveys, it is clear that products with different quality and composition are sold under the same brand in the single market. I consider it inadmissible for us to continue to tolerate a situation where a Czech consumer is offered a product that is of better quality and many times more affordable in a neighboring country. From my point of view, this is a clear deception of the consumer, and for this reason it is necessary to act. Act at Member State level, but also act at EU level. I wonder how you will evaluate the information you are currently requesting from the Member States. However, I think that it is also necessary to commission a comprehensive comparative analysis that would clearly show the scope of these practices and highlight the most critical cases. We have to deal with the problems of the involvement of consumer organizations, producers, traders, but the result should be concrete actions, concrete steps, whether it is better compliance with existing legislation or new legislation.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask you as a consumer, as a customer of the shops in my country, to pay the same price and to consume the same products that you, dear colleagues in the West, consume. The problem of the double standard is pressing for us Easterners. It has been debated for two months and yes, there is nothing concrete, there is not much interest from the Commission or the other states to resolve this division of quality of life. Colleagues from Romania, Slovakia, Hungary have repeatedly asked the Commission to take action on the double food standard, only colleagues representing the eastern part of Europe have called for this. No representative from Western countries was curious to see if its producer, production units in his country, whether we are talking about Germany, Austria, Belgium or France, send goods of a different quality to the East. Europe is not divided into four categories according to the cardinal points, just as the production exported by some large producers should not be divided. I call on the Commission to take action to clarify these hypotheses, to gather evidence from all the Member States of the European Union and to test whether this double-standard phenomenon of products marketed in Eastern Europe is real.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - I mean - great. Today's debate is proof that dual quality is finally becoming a political issue in the EP as well. Unfortunately, this was not the case before, and as has been mentioned by my colleague Biljana Borzan, we have often remained alone in a number of activities. Lastly, when we proposed, for example, reducing dual quality as a discriminatory practice in the geographical blocking regulation. I recall Parliament's resolution of 2013 and the European Commission's approval of my request for a representative survey on the dual quality and evaluation of existing legislation. It is still not fulfilled. The IMCO Committee is now opposing this request and has approved our joint pilot project, which allows for such an extensive survey of food and non-food goods. Dual quality needs to be addressed from the perspective of the EU internal market. In my opinion, this is an unfair commercial practice and discrimination against consumers. It applies not only to food but also to non-food goods. I will be very happy if the conclusions of today's debate are reflected in the support of concrete proposals for solutions.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, both of you have been very busy this week, compliments to you. I listened carefully to the Commissioner’s statements and I think they are logical. Obviously we have to create awareness, and this debate will help to do that. Secondly, getting more evidence; and thirdly, she said enforcement authorities need to cooperate more, and maybe in due course legislation here at European level. There is no doubt about it. I think Mr Peterle put it very well; he said we do not want a two-quality Europe, and definitely this is emerging regarding some food products. If food products have the same packaging throughout the European Union, the same brand name and are marketed as being the same, then we must ensure that the ingredients are the same. We have been given examples of biscuits and fish where this is not the case – fish fingers and probably many more. This has to stop; we have to have equality across Europe – that is what the single market is about, that is what EU citizenship is about. So this is a good debate.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, in the single European market, where the same production and labeling rules apply, it is scandalous that there are products of the same brand, but with different qualities and ingredients in different Member States. It is inexplicable how in countries such as Bulgaria and Slovakia, a cheaper ingredient such as fructose-glucose syrup is used in some beverages, while in the same product, for example in Austria, there is none. I'm not surprised by reactions in the Western press that double standards were "fake news number one." To call analyzes carried out in the state laboratories of the Member States 'fake news' is in itself indicative of the mood among producers in Western Europe. If citizens prefer food with a different and local taste, expensive producers, then produce it under a different brand of raw materials in the country and hire labor there! More than 2 months ago, the Bulgarian Food Safety Agency undertook analyzes on the topic. In just 2 days I was able to identify similar differences in several products. Waiting for dictations from the new government or business is not in the interest of the safety of Bulgarian citizens. It's time for action!

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Mr President, thank you.The existence of double standards for products marketed in Eastern and Western European countries has long been a reality.Recent specialized studies have confirmed the existence of such a worrying situation.At the same time, other studies come and confirm an increased incidence of cancer in the countries of Eastern Europe compared to other countries.The connection between the two realities is clear and unquestionable: poor quality food causes diseases that are often fatal for consumers.The Commission must take firm action in this regard, including by amending existing legislation, in order to avoid double quality standards.And our message is very clear: we do not accept that the countries of the eastern Union become Europe's landfill.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - I am against discrimination against customers and I am in favor of making products of the same quality available to all customers, both in Eastern and Western Europe.That is why I also made a written statement last year, in which we called on the Commission to clear up any issues and ambiguities that upset our citizens.The key question here is whether it is a matter of companies simply adapting the tastes of their products to the habits of the people where those products are sold, or whether it is discriminating against consumers and actually selling lower quality products in Eastern markets.Rather than additional regulation related to both deployment and control costs, it would make sense, in my view, to take action by encouraging testing and comparisons through consumer organizations and informing the public.I conclude ... but I believe that, in addition to the European Commission, the Ministries of Economy of the Member States should also be involved.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Mr President, by signing the parliamentary question but also by speaking, I join all my colleagues in urging the Commission to review EU legislation in order to protect consumers by eliminating double standards in the quality of products sold in Central, Eastern and Western Europe. . I am very pleased that this issue of dual food quality was also raised at the EU summit in March. This topic is more urgent than ever before at this time. We are in the process of Brexit, in the EU the voices of European pessimists and Eurosceptics are stronger, as well as the dual quality of food and the division of people into better and worse, less demanding and more demanding extremist parties to provoke unrest and announce further referendums to leave the EU. Therefore, it is time for the Commission to take swift and vigorous action throughout the supply chain, so that profitable retailers and producers cannot mislead consumers and that any food fraud is properly punished.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman!Commissioner!I just wanted to point out that this is some kind of food adulteration.This problem of food forgery is also very important, especially since at the moment - so to speak - organoleptically we cannot examine these products ourselves.High-class laboratories with new techniques are needed to study these counterfeits.Therefore, I think that this problem requires a central solution at Union level, so that these products can be tested in some way.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear Members, as you mentioned during this very interesting debate for me, there are concrete elements pointing to objective composition differences and as qualitative differences in products sold under the same brand and similar packaging in various countries across Europe. Yes, Mr Jakovčić and all my colleagues, I am very sensitive as a person when it comes to two standards, two qualities, two speeds and so on. It is very important to say that, from my point of view, I do not consider it acceptable that identically-branded products would be deliberately advertised and sold as being the same in different Member States but in fact with a lower quality in one country or another. It is not only about our health but that of our children and next generations. In such a scenario, I think people will rightly feel treated as second-class citizens by industry and perceive that there is no benefit from the single market for them. This said, I must repeat that the companies are not prevented from differentiated products within the EU legislation to better adapt them to the local taste and other conditions – including local market environment – such as competition pressures. As I said in my introductory speech, there is an on-going debate and a process of collecting evidence. This debate will raise awareness, I hope, including for our debate for the benefit of the EU citizens. However, the EU legislation is clear: a product marketed as being the same in several Member States when in fact it presents significant differences in certain countries may be considered as unfairly marketed under consumer protection legislation. Thank you very much for this debate, I will pass the word to my colleague in charge of this issue. I am looking forward to the discussion at the high-level forum on 20 June which I hope will surely also follow up to the debate held here today.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Commissioner, thank you, and as has been said, it is very good that Parliament held this debate today with the Commission, as it has become an issue of political attention in this House. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Gaining consumer confidence is key to the single internal market. Closely related to this is the fact that we must not mislead consumers with quality differences in the basic ingredients of the same products. The harmonization carried out between the Member States is precisely aimed at overcoming such obstacles, so it is unacceptable for there to be significant quality differences in the basic ingredients of the same products in the various countries and regions of the Union. The explanation that some products, such as coffee, are tailored to the tastes of users is still acceptable. However, why the use of washing powder of the same brand and packaging results in clean, fragrant clothes in one country, while its effectiveness lags far behind in another, is already difficult to explain to the different needs of consumers. It is unacceptable, and contrary to not only consumer protection rules but also the principle of the single European internal market, for decades for second-class, lower-quality goods to be available on the shelves in Central and Eastern European countries at the same, and sometimes higher, prices. I do not think that the solution is to set up a 'Nutella police force', but consumers rightly expect the Commission to investigate these cases thoroughly, without bias, in order to put an end to this phenomenon.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - When more than ten years ago our negotiator for joining the EU lightly closed his head, mostly to the detriment of Bulgaria, we wore a lot of silk suits, which promised us almost rivers of prosperity, prosperity and endless happiness in The Community. When we became part of this otherwise good, but dare I say, poorly implemented idea so far, it turned out that these promises were just another lie. We got a government of bureaucrats that no one ever elected. They are very often accused of pursuing or covering up big business policies. Therefore, when it became known that the same product was produced from different products for different parts of the Union, I was not at all surprised. I welcome the colleagues from Eastern Europe who have taken this problem to heart and are looking for a solution. Unfortunately, however, these actions, carried out by corporations and perhaps disguised by bureaucrats, seem to me to be: "We are all equal, but some are more equal" - the motto of an already denied political system, or unfortunately a manifestation of segregation, which contradicts the pillars of development of this Community.
